entry.title: Fair Division 8 Strategic Aspects of Fair Divison
entry.content:
Objective: Investigate strategic aspects of fair division, considering Pure Nash equilibria and fairness.

Activities: Review the paper Allocating Indivisible Goods to Strategic Agents: Pure Nash Equilibria and Fairness.

Abstract

What if the agents are strategic?

Goal: whether there exist mechanisms that have pure Nash Equilibria. If so, what is the fairness guarantee for these equilibria?

Focus on EF1, EFX. The answer is positive.

2 algorithms:

  • round-robin (computing EF1 allocation). Its pure Nash equilibria are EF1 w.r.t. true values.
  • cut and choose algorithm (computing EFX allocation for 2 agents). The corresponding allocations not only are EFX, but also satisfy MMS. A weaker result holds for any mechanism for two agents that always has pure Nash equilibria, which all induce EFX allocations.

Introduction

This paper is interested in exploring the problem from a game-theoretic perspective.

Assume that the agents are strategic, i.e., agent may misreport its true valuation for the goods to end up with a bundle of higher total value.

The algorithm takes the input values (which are probably misreported) the agents declare.

The existence of truthful mechanisms. Even for 2 agents, truthfulness and fairness are incompatible by providing impossibility results for every non-trivial fairness notion. So next natural question: Is it possible to have non-truthful mechanisms that are guaranteed to have equilibria with these equilibria always inducing fair allocations?

Contributions

The class of mechanisms that are implementable in polynomial time have pure Nash equilibria for every instance and provide some fairness guarantee as the allocations they produce in their equilibria is non-empty.

  • Round-robin has pure Nash equilibria for every instance, and these equilibria induce allocations that are known properties of round-robin with a novel recursive construction of â€œnicely structuredâ€ bid profiles.
  • Mod-Cut&Choose has pure Nash equilibria for every instance with 2 agents, and these equilibria induce allocations that are always EFX and MMS w.r.t. the underlying true values. For the case of 2 agents, MMS allocations are always EFX allocations; i.e., MMS fairness is stronger. In non-strategic setting, for any Ïµ>0\epsilon\gt 0Ïµ>0, there are instances in which the output of Mod-Cut&Choose is not (5/6+Ïµ)(5/6+\epsilon)(5/6+Ïµ)-MMS allocation.
  • A weaker result. All mechanisms that have pure Nash equilibria for every instance with 2 agents and these equilibria induce allocations that are always EFX provide stronger MMS guarantees in these allocations than generic EFX allocations do.

Related Works

Omitted

Preliminaries

Goods MMM, agents NNN.

Valuations v\mathbf vv are additive, non-negative.

All the goods must be allocated.

Allocation AAA.

Preference â‰½i,â‰»i\succcurlyeq_i,\succ_iâ‰½iâ€‹,â‰»iâ€‹

Fairness Notions

EF, EF1, EFX

PROP

MMS, Î±\alphaÎ±-MMS

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 1. For n=2n=2n=2, any MMS allocation is also an EFX allocation.

For n=2n=2n=2, MMS allocation is indeed PMMS allocation. Any PMMS allocation is EFX allocation.

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 2. For n=2n=2n=2, any EFX is also 2/32/32/3-MMS allocation. The bound is tight for any mâ‰¥4m\ge4mâ‰¥4.

Mechanisms and Equilibria

An allocation mechanism M\mathcal MM is an algorithm that takes its input from the agents and allocates all the goods to them.

Assume each agent iii reports a bid vector bib_ibiâ€‹, where bijâ‰¥0b_{ij}\ge0bijâ€‹â‰¥0 is the value agent iii claims to have for good gjg_jgjâ€‹. M\mathcal MM takes bid profile b\mathbf bb of bid vectors and outputs an allocation M(b)\mathcal M(\mathbf b)M(b).

Assume that the agents are strategic (They may misreport their true values in order to get a bundle with higher value).

Hence, in general, biâ‰ (vi(g1),â‹¯â€‰,vi(gm))\mathbf b_i\neq(v_i(g_1),\cdots,v_i(g_m))biâ€‹î€ =(viâ€‹(g1â€‹),â‹¯,viâ€‹(gmâ€‹)).

Focus: Fairness guarantees of the pure Nash equilibria of the mechanisms.

Best response.

The profile b\mathbf bb is pure Nash equilibria (PNE) if for each iâˆˆNi\in NiâˆˆN, bi\mathbf b_ibiâ€‹ is a best response to bâˆ’i\mathbf b_{-i}bâˆ’iâ€‹.

When b\mathbf bb is a PNE and the allocation M(b)\mathcal M(\mathbf b)M(b) has a fairness guarantee, we say that b\mathbf bb is EF1.

Some remarks:

  1. Here we donâ€™t consider too much about the complexity of mechanism.
  2. Any PNE of any Î±\alphaÎ±-approximation mechanism for computing MMS allocation is an Î±\alphaÎ±-MMS allocation. This is also true for PROP.

Fairness of Nash Equilibria of Round-Robin

Round-Robin Mechanism takes a bid profile as input. Then RR should also take a permutation NNN as an input to determine the priority of the agents.

WLOG, let the permutation be 1,2,â‹¯â€‰,n1,2,\cdots,n1,2,â‹¯,n.

Itâ€™s known that RR outputs EF1 allocation when all agents have additive valuation functions.

Pseudo-code: Omitted, can refer to here.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 1. If bi\mathbf b_ibiâ€‹ is the truthful bid of agent iii, then the allocation A\mathcal AA returned by Round-Robin is EF1 from iiiâ€™s perspective. Moreover, if i=1i=1i=1, then A\mathcal AA is EF from agent 111â€™s perspective, i.e., âˆ€jâˆˆN,v1(A1)â‰¥v1(Aj)\forall j\in N,v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(A_j)âˆ€jâˆˆN,v1â€‹(A1â€‹)â‰¥v1â€‹(Ajâ€‹).

Truth-telling is not a Pure Nash equilibria. Example omitted.

RR is known to have PNE for any instance in which no agent values two goods exactly the same and at least some such equilibria are easy to compute. Strict preference ranking is convenient as it reduces the number of corner case with which one has to deal. This results can be extended to general additive valuation functions.

For only 2 agents, all PNE of round-robin are EF1 w.r.t. the real valuation functions. Complex even for n=3n=3n=3.

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 3. For any fair division instance with 2 agents, every PNE of RR is EF1 w.r.t. v1,v2v_1,v_2v1â€‹,v2â€‹.

Assume there exists a PNE b=(b1,b2)\mathbf b=(b_1,b_2)b=(b1â€‹,b2â€‹) s.t., in the allocation (A1,A2)(A_1,A_2)(A1â€‹,A2â€‹) returned by RR(b\mathbf bb), at least one of the agents is not EF1-satisfied.

  • If agent 1 is not EF1-satisfied, then is not EF-satisfied either. Because PROP and EF are equivalent for n=2n=2n=2, we have v1(A1)<v1(M)/2v_1(A_1)\lt v_1(M)/2v1â€‹(A1â€‹)<v1â€‹(M)/2. According to Lemma 1, no matter what agent 2 bids, if agent 1 reports true values, the resulting allocation is EF from the agentâ€™s perspective. So, if (A1â€²,A2â€²)(A_1',A_2')(A1â€²â€‹,A2â€²â€‹) is the allocation after agent 1 deviates to the agentâ€™s true values, it is EF-satisfied to agent 1, which contradicts the assumption before.

  • If agent 2 is not EF1-satisfied. Let h1h_1h1â€‹ be the good that agent 1 takes during the first round of RR and gâˆ—âˆˆargâ¡maxâ¡hâˆˆA1v2(h)g^*\in\arg\max_{h\in A_1}v_2(h)gâˆ—âˆˆargmaxhâˆˆA1â€‹â€‹v2â€‹(h) be the highest valued good in A1A_1A1â€‹ according to agent 2.

    Since agent 2 is not EF1-satisfied, v2(A2)<v2(A1â•²{gâˆ—})<v2(A1â•²{h1})v_2(A_2)\lt v_2(A_1\diagdown\{g^*\})\lt v_2(A_1\diagdown\{h_1\})v2â€‹(A2â€‹)<v2â€‹(A1â€‹â•²{gâˆ—})<v2â€‹(A1â€‹â•²{h1â€‹}). This implies that (A1â•²{h1},A2)(A_1\diagdown\{h_1\},A_2)(A1â€‹â•²{h1â€‹},A2â€‹) of Mâ•²{h1}M\diagdown\{h_1\}Mâ•²{h1â€‹} is not EF-satisfied to agent 2.

    Thus v2(A2)â‰¤v2(Mâ•²{h1})/2v_2(A_2)\le v_2(M\diagdown\{h_1\})/2v2â€‹(A2â€‹)â‰¤v2â€‹(Mâ•²{h1â€‹})/2 by the equivalence between EF and PROP for n=2n=2n=2.

    Then suppose agent 2 deviates to reporting the agentâ€™s true values and let (A1â€²,A2â€²)(A_1',A_2')(A1â€²â€‹,A2â€²â€‹) be the resulting allocation. Since the allocation of h1h_1h1â€‹ is not affected by deviation, it is still given to agent 1 in 1st step of RR. Thus the execution of the mechanism would be exactly the same if the input v2v_2v2â€‹ had higher priority than agent 1. This would result in EF w.r.t agent 2 to (A1â€²â•²{h1},A2â€²)(A_1'\diagdown\{h_1\},A_2')(A1â€²â€‹â•²{h1â€‹},A2â€²â€‹). We have v2(A2â€²)â‰¥v2(A1â€²â•²{h1})v_2(A_2')\ge v_2(A_1'\diagdown\{h_1\})v2â€‹(A2â€²â€‹)â‰¥v2â€‹(A1â€²â€‹â•²{h1â€‹}). Therefore v2(A2)â‰¥v2(Mâ•²{h1})/2>v2(A2)v_2(A_2)\ge v_2(M\diagdown\{h_1\})/2\gt v_2(A_2)v2â€‹(A2â€‹)â‰¥v2â€‹(Mâ•²{h1â€‹})/2>v2â€‹(A2â€‹) contradicts the fact that b\mathbf bb is PNE.

The proof doesnâ€™t work for nâ‰¥3n\ge3nâ‰¥3 because there is no equivalence between EF and PROP.

Nash Equilibria of Round-Robin for Any Number of Agents

Agent 1 have no envy toward any other bundle whenever agent 1 bids truthfully. Agent 1 is EF-satisfied.

No matter what agent 1 bids, it is possible to â€œreplaceâ€ the agent with an imaginary version of agent, who

  1. does not affect the allocation
  2. bids truthfully
  3. considers the bundles of the allocation to be as valuable as the original agent 1 though they were

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 4. For any fair division instance I\mathcal II, every PNE of round-robin is EF1 w.r.t. v\mathbf vv.

Proving it reduces to showing that the agent who picks first in the round-robin is EF-satisfied as long as the agent bids a best response to other agentâ€™ bids.

From theorem 5, we know for PNE input, allocation returned by round-robin is EF-satisfied to agent 1.

Fix an agent â„“,â„“â‰¥2\ell,\ell\ge2â„“,â„“â‰¥2. For iâˆˆ[â„“âˆ’1]i\in[\ell-1]iâˆˆ[â„“âˆ’1], let hih_ihiâ€‹ be the good that agent iii claims to be the agentâ€™s favorite among the goods that are available when it is the agentâ€™s turn in the first round, that is hi=argâ¡maxâ¡hâˆˆMâ•²{h1,â‹¯â€‰,hiâˆ’1}bi(h)h_i=\arg\max_{h\in M\diagdown\{h_1,\cdots,h_{i-1}\}}b_i(h)hiâ€‹=argmaxhâˆˆMâ•²{h1â€‹,â‹¯,hiâˆ’1â€‹}â€‹biâ€‹(h). Before â„“\ellâ„“ is first assigned a good, all goods in H={h1,â‹¯â€‰,hâ„“âˆ’1}H=\{h_1,\cdots,h_{\ell-1}\}H={h1â€‹,â‹¯,hâ„“âˆ’1â€‹} have been allocated.

Consider the instance Iâ€²=(N,Mâ•²H,vâ€²)\mathcal I'=(N,M\diagdown H,\mathbf v')Iâ€²=(N,Mâ•²H,vâ€²) in which all goods in HHH are missing.

Consider round-robin on such instance, it starts with agent â„“\ellâ„“ and the follows the indices in increasing order.

Claim that the bid bâ„“â€²\mathbf b_\ell'bâ„“â€²â€‹ is a best response for agent â„“\ellâ„“ assuming that the restricted bid vectors of all the other agents are fixed.

â€¦

Proof is analogous to induction?

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 5. For any fair division instance I\mathcal II, if the reported bid vector b1\mathbf b_1b1â€‹ of agent 1 is a best response to the bid vector bâˆ’1\mathbf b_{-1}bâˆ’1â€‹ of all other players, then agent 1 is EF-satisfied with output.

In PNE, each agentâ€™s bid is a BR to other agentsâ€™ bids. Thus theorem 5 is a corollary to lemma 2.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 2. Suppose that v1v_1v1â€‹ induces a strict preference ranking on the goods. Let b=(b1,bâˆ’1)\mathbf b=(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_{-1})b=(b1â€‹,bâˆ’1â€‹). Then, there exists a valuation function v1âˆ—v_1^*v1âˆ—â€‹ with the following properties:

  • If b1âˆ—\mathbf b_1^*b1âˆ—â€‹ is the truthful bid for v1âˆ—v_1^*v1âˆ—â€‹, then round-robin(b\mathbf bb) and round-robin(b1âˆ—,bâˆ’1\mathbf b_1^*,\mathbf b_{-1}b1âˆ—â€‹,bâˆ’1â€‹) produce the same allocation AAA.
  • v1âˆ—(A1)=v1(A1)v_1^*(A_1)=v_1(A_1)v1âˆ—â€‹(A1â€‹)=v1â€‹(A1â€‹)
  • For every good gâˆˆMâ•²A1g\in M\diagdown A_1gâˆˆMâ•²A1â€‹, it holds that v1âˆ—(g)=v1(g)v_1^*(g)=v_1(g)v1âˆ—â€‹(g)=v1â€‹(g).

Proof of Lemma 2.

EFX Equilibria: The Case of 2 Agents

When the agents are not strategic, EFX exist when nâ‰¤3n\le3nâ‰¤3.

Even for n=3n=3n=3, we are not sure whether there is a polynomial time algorithm.

We consider n=2n=2n=2 in this paper.

Mechanism with EFX Nash Equilibria

A polynomial time algorithm that outputs EFX allocation when we have 2 agents: modified cut-and-choose algorithm in which cut is a variant of envy-cycle-elimination. In this paper, we refer it as â€œMod-Cut&Chooseâ€.

This mechanism is not truthful.

This paper shows that although its non-truthful, Mod-Cut&Choose always has at least one PNE for any instance, and all its equilibria are MMS and EFX. (MMS for 2 agent is PMMS, PMMS is EFX.)

So agent 111 forces the partition that maximizes (according v1v_1v1â€‹) the value of the least desirable bundle according to v2v_2v2â€‹.

Now itâ€™s easy to see that given the bidding strategy of agent 222 (truth-telling), there is no deviation for agent 111 that is profitable. Moreover, agent 222 gets the best of the two bundles according to the agentâ€™s valuation function (truth-telling is dominant strategy for agent 222). Thus, there is no profitable deviation for the agent either. Therefore (b1,b2)(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)(b1â€‹,b2â€‹) is a PNE for I\mathcal II.

Suppose a contradiction that there is a PNE b\mathbf bb, for which an agent iii does not achieve the agentâ€™s Î¼i\mu_iÎ¼iâ€‹ in the allocation returned by Mod-Cut&Choose(b\mathbf bb). If itâ€™s agent 111, then according to Corollary 111, there is a bid vector b1â€²\mathbf b_1'b1â€²â€‹ the agent can report so that the algorithm produces a Î¼1\mu_1Î¼1â€‹-partition. By deviating to b1â€²\mathbf b_1'b1â€²â€‹, regardless of the set given to agent 222, agent 111 ends up with a bundle the agent values at least Î¼1\mu_1Î¼1â€‹. This would be a strict improvement over the agentâ€™s current gain, contradicting that b\mathbf bb is PNE.

So it must be the case that agent 222 gets a bundle that strictly less than Î¼2\mu_2Î¼2â€‹. Regardless of the partition, by declaring the truthful bid, agent 222 gets a bundle of value at least v2(M)/2v_2(M)/2v2â€‹(M)/2. Then itâ€™s immediate to see that this value is at least Î¼2\mu_2Î¼2â€‹, which is a contradiction.

So itâ€™s MMS for 222 agents, thus itâ€™s PMMS, thus EFX.

The Enhanced Fairness of EFX Nash Equilibria

Consider the class of mechanisms that have PNE for every instance, and these equilibria always lead to EFX allocations.

Goal: If these allocations have better fairness guarantees than EFX allocation in general.

2 agents + 4 goods, this paper proved that for every mechanism of this class, all allocations at a PNE are MMS allocations. By Theorem 2, there are instances with just 4 goods in which an EFX allocation is 2/32/32/3-MMS (tight bound).

ğŸ¤”Lemma 5. Consider an instance with 222 agents and 444 goods. If agent iâˆˆ[2]i\in[2]iâˆˆ[2] has strictly positive value for 333 or fewer goods, then in every allocation that is EFX from the agentâ€™s point of view, agent iii has value at least Î¼i\mu_iÎ¼iâ€‹.

Suppose agent iii has positive value for at most 3 goods. The statement is trivial when there is at most one positively valued good as in this case Î¼i=0\mu_i=0Î¼iâ€‹=0, and agent iii always gets Î¼i\mu_iÎ¼iâ€‹ no matter the bundle that agent gets. When agent has a positive value for two goods, in order to consider the allocation as EFX, the agent must get at least one of them. In this case, the agent also achieves the agentâ€™s Î¼i\mu_iÎ¼iâ€‹ as it is equal to the smaller of the 2 positive values.

Suppose agent iii has positive value for 3 goods, notice that Î¼i\mu_iÎ¼iâ€‹ in this case is equal to minâ¡(\min(min(the largest one, the sum of two smallest values))). If agent iii gets 2 goods, then the agent always derives a value of at least Î¼i\mu_iÎ¼iâ€‹. If agent gets just one good, then this good must have the highest value; otherwise the agent wouldnâ€™t consider the allocation as EFX. So agent gets value at least Î¼i\mu_iÎ¼iâ€‹.

    • A1A_1A1â€‹ is one of 24,3424,3424,34. Contradicts PNE.

Thus EFX allocations here are all MMS allocations. Q.E.D.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 6. For N,M,v1N,M,v_1N,M,v1â€‹ as earlier, we have vi({h1,h4})â‰¥Î¼1v_i(\{h_1,h_4\})\ge\mu_1viâ€‹({h1â€‹,h4â€‹})â‰¥Î¼1â€‹ and maxâ¡{vi(h1),vi({h2,h3})}â‰¥Î¼1\max\{v_i(h_1),v_i(\{h_2,h_3\})\}\ge\mu_1max{viâ€‹(h1â€‹),viâ€‹({h2â€‹,h3â€‹})}â‰¥Î¼1â€‹.

For mâ‰¥5m\ge5mâ‰¥5, theorem 7 is not work. Because there are cases donâ€™t lead to contradiction.

We need relaxation on MMS to Î±\alphaÎ±-MMS, but here Î±>2/3\alpha\gt2/3Î±>2/3.

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 8. Let M\mathcal MM be a mechanism that has PNE for any instance ([2],M,(v1,v2))([2],\mathcal M,(v_1,v_2))([2],M,(v1â€‹,v2â€‹)) and all these equilibria lead to EFX allocation w.r.t. v1,v2v_1,v_2v1â€‹,v2â€‹. Then, each such EFX allocation is also an Î±\alphaÎ±-MMS with Î±>2/3\alpha\gt2/3Î±>2/3.

Suppose for contradiction: there exists such a mechanism M\mathcal MM and an instance ({1,2},M,(v1,v2))(\{1,2\},M,(v_1,v_2))({1,2},M,(v1â€‹,v2â€‹)) for which there is a PNE b=(b1,b2)\mathbf b=(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)b=(b1â€‹,b2â€‹) that results in an EFX allocation A\mathcal AA, where vi(Ai)â‰¤2Î¼i/3v_i(A_i)\le2\mu_i/3viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¤2Î¼iâ€‹/3 for at least one iâˆˆ[2]i\in[2]iâˆˆ[2]. WLOG, assume v1(A1)â‰¤2Î¼1/3v_1(A_1)\le2\mu_1/3v1â€‹(A1â€‹)â‰¤2Î¼1â€‹/3. By Theorem 2, this implies v1(A1)=2Î¼1/3v_1(A_1)=2\mu_1/3v1â€‹(A1â€‹)=2Î¼1â€‹/3. Thus v1(A2)â‰¥4Î¼i/3v_1(A_2)\ge4\mu_i/3v1â€‹(A2â€‹)â‰¥4Î¼iâ€‹/3 because v1(M)â‰¥2Î¼1v_1(M)\ge2\mu_1v1â€‹(M)â‰¥2Î¼1â€‹ by definition of MMS.

Initially, we restrict # goods with positive value in A2A_2A2â€‹. Let SâŠ†A2S\subseteq A_2SâŠ†A2â€‹ be the set of such goods. Let âˆ£Sâˆ£=k|S|=kâˆ£Sâˆ£=k and notice that kkk canâ€™t be 000 or 111. Finally, let xâˆˆargâ¡minâ¡gâˆˆSv1(g)x\in\arg\min_{g\in S}v_1(g)xâˆˆargmingâˆˆSâ€‹v1â€‹(g) be a minimum valued good for agent 111 in SSS. We have

23Î¼1=v1(A1)â‰¥v1(Sâ•²{x})â‰¥v1(S)âˆ’v1(S)k=kâˆ’1kv1(A2)â‰¥kâˆ’1k43Î¼1,\frac{2}{3}\mu_1=v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(S\diagdown\{x\})\ge v_1(S)-\frac{v_1(S)}{k}=\frac{k-1}{k}v_1(A_2)\ge\frac{k-1}{k}\frac{4}{3}\mu_1,32â€‹Î¼1â€‹=v1â€‹(A1â€‹)â‰¥v1â€‹(Sâ•²{x})â‰¥v1â€‹(S)âˆ’kv1â€‹(S)â€‹=kkâˆ’1â€‹v1â€‹(A2â€‹)â‰¥kkâˆ’1â€‹34â€‹Î¼1â€‹,

where the first inequality follows from EFX. Observe that kâ‰¤2k\le2kâ‰¤2, this implies k=2k=2k=2.

â€¦ Yet another long proof

Discussion

This paper discusses fair division with indivisible goods to a set of strategic agents.

Surprisingly, there exists strong impossibilities for truthful mechanisms. The paper shows that there exist mechanisms that have PNE for every instance, and at the same time the PNE allocation have strong guarantees w.r.t. true valuations.

Possible directions for future work:

  • Algorithm that compute EF1 allocations for richer valuation function domains (Envy-cycle elimination) in strategic setting.

    • Does there exist pure or mixed Nash Equilibria?
    • If there exist NE, does it still maintain fairness properties at the NE?

  • Theorem 7&8 leave an open problem: MMS guarantee that the equilibria of mechanisms that always have PNE and these are EFX.

    • suspect: corresponding allocations are not always MMS.
    • For every such mechanism that runs in polynomial time, finding a best response of an agent is NP. For nâ‰¥3n\ge3nâ‰¥3 the problem is absolutely non-trivial.

  • The complexity for computing best response. Want to know if best response dynamics always converge to a PNE or there might be cyclic behavior?

entry.title: æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ 13 Sequence Segmentation and Similarities
entry.content:
How to segment a sequence of points with an efficient algorithms and how to find similar documents in a linear manner.

2 algorithm.

The first is clustering a sequence to form kkk partitions with a dynamic programming.

The second is an approximation that allows to compute pairwise distance avoiding O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2). The idea is to use efficient signatures and hash the signatures in bands so as similar items will likely end up in the same bucket.

Sequence Segmentation

A sequence is a vector (x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)âˆˆRn(x_1,\cdots, x_n)\in\mathbb R^n(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)âˆˆRn.

Sequence segmentation: Given a set sequence (x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)(x_1,\cdots,x_n)(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹), find kkk contiguous segments that are as homogeneous as possible.

The sequence segmentation problem requires a notion of homogeneity similar to one of clustering. Points in the segment should be subsequences rendering the problem different from that of clustering.

A sequence is homogeneous if its points have a small deviation from the mean. Let D\mathcal DD be a sequence of nnn ddd-dimensional points.

Definition of kkk-segmentation: A kkk-segmentation SSS is a partition of D\mathcal DD into kkk contiguous segments (s1,â‹¯â€‰,sk)(s_1,\cdots,s_k)(s1â€‹,â‹¯,skâ€‹). Each segment sis_isiâ€‹ is represented by a ddd-dimensional mean vector Î¼i=1âˆ£sâˆ£âˆ‘xâˆˆsx\mu_i=\frac{1}{|s|}\sum_{\mathbb x\in s}\mathbb xÎ¼iâ€‹=âˆ£sâˆ£1â€‹âˆ‘xâˆˆsâ€‹x.

The mean vector has the same role of the centroid for kkk-means clustering. The error E(S)E(S)E(S) of a kkk-segmentation SSS is the error of replacing each individual point with the means. Similar to kkk-means, one of the most common errors is sum of squares error:

E(S)=âˆ‘sâˆˆSâˆ‘sâˆˆS(xâˆ’Î¼s)2E(S)=\sum_{s\in S}\sum_{\mathbb s\in S}(\mathbb x-\mu_s)^2E(S)=sâˆˆSâˆ‘â€‹sâˆˆSâˆ‘â€‹(xâˆ’Î¼sâ€‹)2

Problem of k-segmentation problem

Given a sequence D=(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)\mathcal D=(\mathbb x_1,\cdots,\mathbb x_n)D=(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹) of length nnn, find a set of kkk segments SSS of D\mathcal DD s.t. the SSE error is minimized.

A Dynamic Programming Solution

A dynamic programming solution from Bellman solves the kkk-segmentation problem in polynomial time.

The idea is to build the solution bottom-up solving progressively larger instances of the problem.

DP requires the property of optimal sub-problem that states that the solution on a subset of the input is also optimal.

Denote D[1,i]D[1,i]D[1,i] the sub-sequence x1,â‹¯â€‰,xi\mathbb x_1,\cdots,\mathbb x_ix1â€‹,â‹¯,xiâ€‹ with iâ‰¤ni\le niâ‰¤n. E(i,s)E(i,s)E(i,s) is the error of the optimal segmentation of the sub-sequence D[1,i]D[1,i]D[1,i] with sss segments with sâ‰¤ks\le ksâ‰¤k. The dynamic programming algorithm follows the recursion

E(i,s)=minâ¡sâ‰¤jâ‰¤iâˆ’1(E(j,sâˆ’1)+âˆ‘j+1â‰¤tâ‰¤i(tâˆ’Î¼j+1,i)2)E(i,s)=\min_{s\le j\le i-1}\left(E(j,s-1)+\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}(\mathbf t-\mu_{j+1,i})^2\right)E(i,s)=sâ‰¤jâ‰¤iâˆ’1minâ€‹(E(j,sâˆ’1)+j+1â‰¤tâ‰¤iâˆ‘â€‹(tâˆ’Î¼j+1,iâ€‹)2)

In practice we can use a 2-dimensional table that stores in position s,is,is,i the value E(i,s)E(i,s)E(i,s).

Pseudo-code

Input: Sequence D,k,E(â‹…)\mathcal D,k,E(\cdot)D,k,E(â‹…)

  1. for each iâ†1â‹¯ni\gets1\cdots niâ†1â‹¯n do
    • A[1,i]=E(D[1â‹¯i])A[1,i]=E(D[1\cdots i])A[1,i]=E(D[1â‹¯i])
  2. for each sâ†1â‹¯ks\gets1\cdots ksâ†1â‹¯k do
    • A[s,s]=0A[s,s]=0A[s,s]=0
  3. for each s=2â‹¯ns=2\cdots ns=2â‹¯n do
    • for each i=s+1,â‹¯â€‰,ni=s+1,\cdots,ni=s+1,â‹¯,n do
      • A[k,i]=minâ¡j<i(A[sâˆ’1,j]+E(D[j+1â‹¯i]))A[k,i]=\min_{j\lt i}(A[s-1,j]+E(D[j+1\cdots i]))A[k,i]=minj<iâ€‹(A[sâˆ’1,j]+E(D[j+1â‹¯i]))

To recover the actual segmentation, the matrix AAA should store also the values jjj minimizing the error.

Complexity

The algorithm needs to fill O(nk)\mathcal O(nk)O(nk) table, each cell computes the minimum, takes O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n) cells to check, each of it computes the error in O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n). Thus total complexity of O(n3k)\mathcal O(n^3k)O(n3k) for naive version.

The errors per cell can be further optimized by noticing that

âˆ‘j+1â‰¤tâ‰¤i(tâˆ’Î¼[j+1,i])2=âˆ‘j+1â‰¤tâ‰¤it2âˆ’1iâˆ’j(âˆ‘j+1â‰¤tâ‰¤it)2\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}(\mathbf t-\mu_{[j+1,i]})^2=\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}\mathbf t^2-\frac{1}{i-j}(\sum_{j+1\le t\le i}\mathbf t)^2j+1â‰¤tâ‰¤iâˆ‘â€‹(tâˆ’Î¼[j+1,i]â€‹)2=j+1â‰¤tâ‰¤iâˆ‘â€‹t2âˆ’iâˆ’j1â€‹(j+1â‰¤tâ‰¤iâˆ‘â€‹t)2

that requires the repeated computation of t2\mathbf t^2t2 and t\mathbf tt. These two terms can be easily pre-computed for all i=1â‹¯ni=1\cdots ni=1â‹¯n. By this optimization, complexity is reduced to O(n2k)\mathbf O(n^2k)O(n2k).

Heuristic: we can further reduce the computational burden by using greedy approaches or local search that assigns border points randomly and move the in a way to reduce the errors. The total time is O(nk)\mathcal O(nk)O(nk).

Finding Similar Points Efficiently

Comparing each point in the data with other, raising O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2).

Given a dataset D={x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn}\mathcal D=\{\mathbb x_1,\cdots,\mathbb x_n\}D={x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹} of ddd-dimensional data points, find all the pairs of data point (xi,xj)(\mathbb x_i,\mathbb x_j)(xiâ€‹,xjâ€‹) s.t. d(xi,xj)â‰¤sd(\mathbb x_i,\mathbb x_j)\le sd(xiâ€‹,xjâ€‹)â‰¤s for some distance function ddd.

With Locality-Sensitive Hashing, we can get rid of O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2).

LSH ä¸æ˜¯ ä»Šå¤©ä¸Šåˆçš„éšæœºç®—æ³•è¯¾ æ‰è®²çš„ä¹ˆâ€¦â€¦è¿™ä¸‹é—­ç¯äº†ã€‚

Definition of Jaccard similarity: of two sets is the size of their intersection sim(C_1,C_2)=|C_1\and C_2|/|C_1\or C_2|. The Jaccard distance is then d(C_1,C_2)=1-|C_1\and C_2|/|C_1\or C_2|.

A large number of documents do not fit into memory and we need a representation of each document that allows for preserving the distances while considerably reducing the memory footprint. In order to achieve such a gold, we use the 3 steps:

  1. Shingling: Convert documents to sets.
  2. Min-hashing: Convert large sets to short signatures, while preserving similarity.
  3. LSH: Focus on pairs of signatures likely to be from similar documents.

Shingling

A kkk-shingle is a set of kkk tokens that appear in the document.

Idea: we return a large number of sparse vector with low similarity.

For instance, the set of 222-shingle for document D1=abcabD_1=abcabD1â€‹=abcab is S(D1)={ab,bc,ca}S(D_1)=\{ab,bc,ca\}S(D1â€‹)={ab,bc,ca}.

Long shingles can be easily compressed by hashing. Documents are compared through the hash values. Finally each document is a binary vector in the space of kkk-shingle in which a shingle is a dimension.

We assume that documents have a large number of common shingles if they are similar. However, kkk is a critical choice to compare documents. A small kkk leads to a large number of similar documents. As rule of thumb k=5,10k=5,10k=5,10 is a reasonable choice for short/large documents.

Shingling doesnâ€™t solve the problem of a large number of similarity computation.

Min-hash

The document is converted into a set of shingles and consequently as a binary vector, where each dimension is a shingle and a 111 in position iii of document jjj indicates that the document contains the shingle iii. This way can we represent our dataset as a matrix where each row represents.

Computing Jaccard similarity in such a matrix relies on simple bit-wise AND, intersection and OR.

Min-Hashing is used for faster comparison. It converts the binary representation into small signatures through hashing. The key idea is to hash each column to a small signatures h(C)h(C)h(C) s.t.

  • h(C)h(C)h(C) is small enough that the signature fits in RAM
  • sim(C1,C2)sim(C_1,C_2)sim(C1â€‹,C2â€‹) is the same as the similarity of signatures h(C1),h(C2)h(C_1),h(C_2)h(C1â€‹),h(C2â€‹).

Definition of min-hash function: The hash function hÏ€(C)h_\pi(C)hÏ€â€‹(C) returns the index of the first row in which column CCC has value 111.

hÏ€(C)=minâ¡Ï€(C)h_\pi(C)=\min_\pi(C)hÏ€â€‹(C)=Ï€minâ€‹(C)

Hash function is a approximation of a set.

Min-hash preserves the property that Prâ¡[hÏ€(C1)=hÏ€(C2)]=sim(C1,C2)\Pr[h_\pi(C_1)=h_\pi(C_2)]=sim(C_1,C_2)Pr[hÏ€â€‹(C1â€‹)=hÏ€â€‹(C2â€‹)]=sim(C1â€‹,C2â€‹).

A trick

For each column CCC, and hash function, kik_ikiâ€‹ keep a slot for the min-hash value. Initialize Sig(C)[i]=âˆSig(C)[i]=\inftySig(C)[i]=âˆ, then scan rows looking for 111s. How to choose kik_ikiâ€‹? Using universal hashing.

åˆæ˜¯éšæœºç®—æ³•å‰é¢å­¦è¿‡çš„ä¸œè¥¿ã€‚

LSH

LSH tackles the problem of the comparison by hashing the signatures in an appropriate manner.

Intuition: use a function f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) to determine whether xxx and yyy is a candidate pair whose similarity must be evaluated. For Min-hash matrices we hash the columns of the signature matrix MMM to different buckets. If two documents hashes into the same buckets, they become a candidate pair with similarity simâ‰¥thresholdsim\ge thresholdsimâ‰¥threshold.

LSH works:

  • Pick a similarity threshold sss.
  • The columns of xxx and yyy of MMM are a candidate pair if their signatures agree on at least a fraction sss of their rows. M(i,x)=M(i,y)M(i,x)=M(i,y)M(i,x)=M(i,y) for at least a fraction sss of iii.
  • The idea is to hash columns of signatures matrix MMM several times. Similar columns should be likely to hash to the same bucket with high probability.

LSH partitions MMMâ€™s columns into bbb bands each of rrr rows. For each band, compute a signatures using a hash function with kkk buckets, where kkk is arbitrarily large. The candidate column pairs are those that hash to the same bucket for at least 111 band. Tune bbb and rrr to catch most similar pairs, few non-similar pairs.

How to choose bbb and rrr?

Balances false positives / negatives.

We need to strike a trade-off with the number of bands and the number of rows.

As bbb increases, the method becomes more reliable, but the time increases as well.

If t=sim(C1,C2)t=sim(C_1,C_2)t=sim(C1â€‹,C2â€‹) the probability that all rows in a band are equal is trt^rtr and probability that some row in a band are different is 1âˆ’tr1-t^r1âˆ’tr.

As such the probability that no band is identical is (1âˆ’rt)b(1-r^t)^b(1âˆ’rt)b that leads to (1âˆ’(1âˆ’rt)b)(1-(1-r^t)^b)(1âˆ’(1âˆ’rt)b) the probability that at least 111 band is identical.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘Finds similar items in linear time

ğŸ‘Easy and fast to implement

ğŸ‘Generalizes to other similarity measures

ğŸ‘Performance depend on the choice of b,rb,rb,r

ğŸ‘Requres a fairly large number of buckets
entry.summary:
How to segment a sequence of points with an efficient algorithms and how to find similar documents in a linear manner.

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 12 Nearest Neighbor Search and Locality Sensitive Hashing
entry.content:
Nearest Neighbor Search

2D scenario: Voronoi Diagram

3D or higher dimensions: Not efficient.

Fine-grained complexity

Approximate nearest neighbor search

Assume the distance between query point and its nearest neighbor is RRR, ccc-approximate RRR-near neighbor is all the points within range cR(câ‰¥1)cR(c\ge1)cR(câ‰¥1).

  • input: point qqq, constant ccc, radium RRR.
  • if there is a point ppp with dist(p,q)â‰¤Rdist(p,q)\le Rdist(p,q)â‰¤R, then return point pâ€²p'pâ€² with dist(pâ€²,q)â‰¤cRdist(p',q)\le cRdist(pâ€²,q)â‰¤cR with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´\ge 1-\deltaâ‰¥1âˆ’Î´.

Locality Sensitive Hashing

abbr. LSH

Distance: dist:RdÃ—Rdâ†’Rdist:\mathbb R^d\times\mathbb R^d\rarr\mathbb Rdist:RdÃ—Rdâ†’R. â„“1,â„“2\ell_1,\ell_2â„“1â€‹,â„“2â€‹, Manhattan, Hammingâ€¦

Hash function hhh is (R,cR,P1,P2)(R,cR,P_1,P_2)(R,cR,P1â€‹,P2â€‹)-sensitive w.r.t. distdistdist if

  1. âˆ€p,q\forall p,qâˆ€p,q with dist(p,q)â‰¤R:Prâ¡[h(p)=h(q)]â‰¥P1dist(p,q)\le R:\Pr[h(p)=h(q)]\ge P_1dist(p,q)â‰¤R:Pr[h(p)=h(q)]â‰¥P1â€‹.
  2. âˆ€p,q\forall p,qâˆ€p,q with dist(p,q)â‰¥cR:Prâ¡[h(p)=h(q)]â‰¤P2dist(p,q)\ge cR:\Pr[h(p)=h(q)]\le P_2dist(p,q)â‰¥cR:Pr[h(p)=h(q)]â‰¤P2â€‹.
  3. P1â‰¥P2P_1\ge P_2P1â€‹â‰¥P2â€‹.

Store all points pâˆˆSp\in SpâˆˆS in hash table with key h(p)h(p)h(p) which hhh is (R,cR,P1,P2)(R,cR,P_1,P_2)(R,cR,P1â€‹,P2â€‹)-sensitive.

A[y]A[y]A[y] is linked list of all points pâ€²âˆˆSp'\in Spâ€²âˆˆS with h(pâ€²)=yh(p')=yh(pâ€²)=y,

Query:

Let XpX_pXpâ€‹ be 111 if h(p)=h(q)h(p)=h(q)h(p)=h(q) and 000 otherwise.

E[âˆ‘pXp]=âˆ‘pE[Xp]=âˆ‘pPrâ¡h[h(p)=h(q)]\mathbb E[\sum_pX_p]=\sum_p\mathbb E[X_p]=\sum_p\Pr_h[h(p)=h(q)]E[pâˆ‘â€‹Xpâ€‹]=pâˆ‘â€‹E[Xpâ€‹]=pâˆ‘â€‹hPrâ€‹[h(p)=h(q)]

Parameter kkk, g(p)g(p)g(p) is the concatenates of 0âˆ’10-10âˆ’1 bits of h1(p),â‹¯â€‰,hk(p)h_1(p),\cdots,h_k(p)h1â€‹(p),â‹¯,hkâ€‹(p). hih_ihiâ€‹ are independent.

For dist(p,q)â‰¤Rdist(p,q)\le Rdist(p,q)â‰¤R, Prâ¡g[g(p)=g(q)]â‰¥P1k\Pr_g[g(p)=g(q)]\ge P_1^kPrgâ€‹[g(p)=g(q)]â‰¥P1kâ€‹.

For dist(p,q)â‰¥Rdist(p,q)\ge Rdist(p,q)â‰¥R, Prâ¡g[g(p)=g(q)]â‰¤P2kâ‰¤1/n\Pr_g[g(p)=g(q)]\le P_2^k\le1/nPrgâ€‹[g(p)=g(q)]â‰¤P2kâ€‹â‰¤1/n.

Let XpX_pXpâ€‹ be 111 if g(p)=g(q)g(p)=g(q)g(p)=g(q) and 000 otherwise.

E[âˆ‘pXp]=âˆ‘dist(p,q)â‰¥cRPrâ¡[g(p)=g(q)]+âˆ‘dist(p,q)â‰¤RPrâ¡[g(p)=g(q)]\mathbb E[\sum_pX_p]=\sum_{dist(p,q)\ge cR}\Pr[g(p)=g(q)]+\sum_{dist(p,q)\le R}\Pr[g(p)=g(q)]E[pâˆ‘â€‹Xpâ€‹]=dist(p,q)â‰¥cRâˆ‘â€‹Pr[g(p)=g(q)]+dist(p,q)â‰¤Râˆ‘â€‹Pr[g(p)=g(q)]

Choosing k=logâ¡P2(1/n)k=\log_{P_2}(1/n)k=logP2â€‹â€‹(1/n)

Better probability:

For parameters L,kL,kL,k. For i=1,â‹¯â€‰,Li=1,\cdots,Li=1,â‹¯,L, gi(p)g_i(p)giâ€‹(p) is the concatenates of 0âˆ’10-10âˆ’1 bits of hi1(p),â‹¯â€‰,hik(p)h_{i1}(p),\cdots,h_{ik}(p)hi1â€‹(p),â‹¯,hikâ€‹(p). hih_ihiâ€‹ are independent.

Distance metric: Hamming distance.

for i=1,â‹¯â€‰,Li=1,\cdots,Li=1,â‹¯,L: store SSS in hash table HiH_iHiâ€‹.

Query(q):

  • For i=1,â‹¯â€‰,Li=1,\cdots,Li=1,â‹¯,L

    • scan list Hi[gi(q)]H_i[g_i(q)]Hiâ€‹[giâ€‹(q)]:

      if see ppp with dist(p,q)â‰¤cRdist(p,q)\le cRdist(p,q)â‰¤cR

      • return p

    • if scan >3L>3L>3L points

      • abort

Space: O(Ln+nd)O(Ln+nd)O(Ln+nd)

Query time: O(Lkt+Ld)O(Lkt+Ld)O(Lkt+Ld) LLL is time to evaluate hhh.

Probability Bound for Failure

Two types of failure:

E1={âˆ€i:gi(q)â‰ gi(pâˆ—)}E_1=\{\forall_i:g_i(q)\ne g_i(p^*)\}E1â€‹={âˆ€iâ€‹:giâ€‹(q)î€ =giâ€‹(pâˆ—)}

E_2=\{\sum_{i=1}^L|\{p:dist(p,q)\gt cR\and g_i(q)=g_i(p)\}|\gt3L\}

If none of them happens, the results is correct.

We want Prâ¡[E1âˆªE2]â‰¤Prâ¡[E1]+Prâ¡[E2]â‰¤1/2\Pr[E_1\cup E_2]\le\Pr[E_1]+\Pr[E_2]\le1/2Pr[E1â€‹âˆªE2â€‹]â‰¤Pr[E1â€‹]+Pr[E2â€‹]â‰¤1/2.

\Pr[E_2]\le\mathbb E[\sum_{i=1}^L|\{p:dist(p,q)\gt cR\and g_i(q)=g_i(p)\}|]/3L\\=\sum_{i=1}^L....\\\le L/3L=1/3\\\Pr[E_1]=\Pr[\forall i:g_i(p)\neq g_i(p^*)]\\=\prod_{i=1}^L\Pr[g_i(q)\neq g_i(p^*)]\\=\prod_{i=1}^L(1-\Pr[g_i(q)=g_i(p^*)])\\=(1-P_1^k)^L\\

Choosing L=logâ¡1âˆ’P1k16L=\log_{1-P_1^k}\frac{1}{6}L=log1âˆ’P1kâ€‹â€‹61â€‹, we will get 1/21/21/2 probability bound for failure.

Upper bound for L

L=lnâ¡1/6lnâ¡(1âˆ’P1k)â‰¤lnâ¡(1/6)lnâ¡(expâ¡(âˆ’P1k))=lnâ¡1/6âˆ’P1k=lnâ¡6/P1k=O(P1âˆ’k)P1âˆ’k=1P1logâ¡P21/n=â‹¯â‹¯=nlnâ¡P1/lnâ¡P2=nlnâ¡(1/P1)/lnâ¡(1/P2)L=\frac{\ln 1/6}{\ln(1-P_1^k)}\le\frac{\ln(1/6)}{\ln(\exp(-P_1^k))}=\frac{\ln1/6}{-P_1^k}=\ln6/P_1^k=O(P_1^{-k})\\P_1^{-k}=\frac{1}{P_1^{\log_{P_2}1/n}}\\=\cdots\cdots\\=n^{\ln P_1/\ln P_2}=n^{\ln(1/P_1)/\ln(1/P_2)}L=ln(1âˆ’P1kâ€‹)ln1/6â€‹â‰¤ln(exp(âˆ’P1kâ€‹))ln(1/6)â€‹=âˆ’P1kâ€‹ln1/6â€‹=ln6/P1kâ€‹=O(P1âˆ’kâ€‹)P1âˆ’kâ€‹=P1logP2â€‹â€‹1/nâ€‹1â€‹=â‹¯â‹¯=nlnP1â€‹/lnP2â€‹=nln(1/P1â€‹)/ln(1/P2â€‹)

For hamming distance:

P1=1âˆ’R/dP2=1âˆ’cR/dsupâ¡L=n1/cP_1=1-R/d\\P_2=1-cR/d\\\sup L=n^{1/c}P1â€‹=1âˆ’R/dP2â€‹=1âˆ’cR/dsupL=n1/c

Digest from Reference Paper

Efficient algorithms for the approximate and exact nearest neighbor problem.

Goal: Preprocess a dataset of objects. Later, given a new query object, one can quickly return the dataset object that is most similar to the query.

Nearest Neighbor Problem

Given a collection of nnn points, build a data structure which, given any query point, reports the data point that is closest to the query.

A point Rd\mathbb R^dRd and the distance metric. Itâ€™s hard when ddd is large.

In approximation version, the algorithm is allowed to return a point whose distance from the query is at most ccc times the distance from the query to its nearest points.

c>1c\gt1c>1 is called the approximation factor.

One of the most popular algorithms for performing approximate search in high dimensions based on locality-sensitive hashing.

Key idea: hash the point using several hash functions to ensure that for each function, the probability of collision is much higher for objects that are close to each other than for those that are far apart. Then one can determine near neighbors by hashing the query point and retrieving elements stored in buckets containing that point.

Definitions

We say point ppp is an RRR-near neighbor of a point qqq if the distance between ppp and qqq is at most RRR.

Definition of Randomized ccc-approximate RRR-near neighbor (abbr. (c,R)(c,R)(c,R)-NN). Given a set PPP of points in a ddd-dimensional space Rd\mathbb R^dRd, and parameters R>0,Î´>0R\gt0,\delta\gt0R>0,Î´>0, construct a data structure s.t., given any query point qqq, if there exits an RRR-near neighbor of qqq in PPP, it reports some cRcRcR-near neighbor of qqq in PPP with probability 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´.

  • We can assume R=1R=1R=1, just by simply dividing all coordinates by RRR. Thus ccc-NN.

Definition of Randomized RRR-near neighbor reporting. Given a set PPP of points in a ddd-dimensional space Rd\mathbb R^dRd, and parameter R>0,Î´>0R\gt0,\delta\gt0R>0,Î´>0, construct a data structure that, given any query point qqq, reports each RRR-near neighbor of qqq in PPP with probability 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´.

Locality-Sensitive Hash Function

The LSH algorithm relies on the existence of locality-sensitive hash functions.

Let H\mathcal HH be a family of hash functions mapping Rd\mathbb R^dRd to some universe UUU. For any 2 point ppp and qqq, consider a process in which we choose a function hhh from H\mathcal HH uniformly at random, and analyze the probability that h(p)=h(q)h(p)=h(q)h(p)=h(q).

The family H\mathcal HH is called (R,cR,P1,P2)(R,cR,P_1,P_2)(R,cR,P1â€‹,P2â€‹)-sensitive if any two points p,qâˆˆRdp,q\in\mathbb R^dp,qâˆˆRd.

  • if âˆ¥pâˆ’qâˆ¥â‰¤R\Vert p-q\Vert\le Râˆ¥pâˆ’qâˆ¥â‰¤R then Prâ¡H[h(q)=h(p)]â‰¥P1\Pr_\mathcal H[h(q)=h(p)]\ge P_1PrHâ€‹[h(q)=h(p)]â‰¥P1â€‹
  • if âˆ¥pâˆ’qâˆ¥â‰¥cR\Vert p-q\Vert\ge cRâˆ¥pâˆ’qâˆ¥â‰¥cR then Prâ¡H[h(q)=h(p)]â‰¤P2\Pr_\mathcal H[h(q)=h(p)]\le P_2PrHâ€‹[h(q)=h(p)]â‰¤P2â€‹

å¦‚æœä¸¤ä¸ªç‚¹å¾ˆæ¥è¿‘çš„è¯ï¼Œé‚£å®ƒä»¬å“ˆå¸Œç¢°æ’çš„æ¦‚ç‡å¾ˆé«˜ã€‚

å¦‚æœä¸¤ä¸ªç‚¹å¾ˆè¿œçš„è¯ï¼Œé‚£å®ƒä»¬å“ˆå¸Œç¢°æ’çš„æ¦‚ç‡å¾ˆä½ã€‚

In order for a locality-sensitive hash (LSH) family to be useful, it has to satisfy P1>P2P_1\gt P_2P1â€‹>P2â€‹.

LSH Algorithm

An LSH family H\mathcal HH is used for efficient algorithm for approximate near neighbor search.

We need to amplify the gap between P1P_1P1â€‹ ad P2P_2P2â€‹.

For parameters kkk and LLL, we choose LLL functions gj(q)=(h1,j(q),â‹¯â€‰,hk,j(q))g_j(q)=(h_{1,j}(q),\cdots,h_{k,j}(q))gjâ€‹(q)=(h1,jâ€‹(q),â‹¯,hk,jâ€‹(q)), where ht,j(1<t<k,1<j<L)h_{t,j}(1\lt t\lt k,1\lt j\lt L)ht,jâ€‹(1<t<k,1<j<L) are chosen independently and uniformly at random from H\mathcal HH. We are also given a distance function dist: RdÃ—Rdâ†’R\mathbb R^d\times\mathbb R^d\rarr\mathbb RRdÃ—Rdâ†’R. These are the actual functions that we use to hash the data points.

The data structure is constructed by placing each point ppp from the input set into a bucket gj(p)g_j(p)gjâ€‹(p). This way the data structure uses only O(nL)O(nL)O(nL) memory. It suffices that buckets store the pointers to data points, not the points themselves.

To process a query qqq, we scan through the buckets g1(q),â‹¯â€‰,gL(q)g_1(q),\cdots,g_L(q)g1â€‹(q),â‹¯,gLâ€‹(q), and retrieve the points stored in them. If there is an RRR-near neighbor ppp of qqq dist(p,q)â‰¤Rdist(p,q)\le Rdist(p,q)â‰¤R, we must report some point pâ€²p'pâ€² that is a cRcRcR-near neighbor of qqq.

Two concrete scanning strategies:

  1. Interrupt the search after finding the first Lâ€²L'Lâ€² points for some parameter Lâ€²L'Lâ€².

    (c,R)(c,R)(c,R)-near neighbor problem

    With Lâ€²=3LL'=3LLâ€²=3L, yields a solution to the randomized ccc-approximate RRR-near neighbor problem, with RRR and Î´\deltaÎ´ for some constant failure probability Î´<1\delta\lt1Î´<1. To obtain this guarantee, it suffices to set LLL to Î˜(nÏ)\Theta(n^\rho)Î˜(nÏ), where Ï=lnâ¡1/P1lnâ¡1/P2\rho=\frac{\ln 1/P_1}{\ln 1/P_2}Ï=ln1/P2â€‹ln1/P1â€‹â€‹.

  2. Continue the search until all points from all buckets are retrieved

    RRR-near neighbor reporting problem

    The value of the failure probability Î´\deltaÎ´ depends on the choice of the parameters kkk and LLL. For each Î´\deltaÎ´, one can provide parameters kkk and LLL so that the error probability is smaller than Î´\deltaÎ´. The query time is also dependent on kkk and LLL, the worst case could be as high as Î˜(n)\Theta(n)Î˜(n). But for many natural datasets, a proper choice of parameters results in a sublinear query time.

    The details of the analysis are as follows. Let ppp be any RRR-neighbor of qqq, consider any parameter kkk. For any function gig_igiâ€‹, the probability that gi(p)=gi(q)g_i(p)=g_i(q)giâ€‹(p)=giâ€‹(q) for some i=1,â‹¯â€‰,Li=1,\cdots,Li=1,â‹¯,L is at least 1âˆ’(1âˆ’P1k)L1-(1-P_1^k)^L1âˆ’(1âˆ’P1kâ€‹)L. If we set L=logâ¡1âˆ’P1kÎ´L=\log_{1-P_1^k}\deltaL=log1âˆ’P1kâ€‹â€‹Î´ so that (1âˆ’P1k)Lâ‰¤Î´(1-P_1^k)^L\le\delta(1âˆ’P1kâ€‹)Lâ‰¤Î´, then any RRR-neighbor of qqq is returned by the algorithm with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´.

    How to choose kkk? Larger kkk lead to a larger gap between the probabilities of collision for close points and far points.

LSH Library

Several distance metrics is defined here.

Hamming distance, â„“1\ell_1â„“1â€‹ distance, â„“s\ell_sâ„“sâ€‹ distance, Jaccard, Arccos etc.

Near-Optimal LSH Function for Eucildean Distance

A new LSH family, yielding an algorithm with query time exponent Ï(c)=1/c2+O(logâ¡logâ¡n/logâ¡1/3n)\rho(c)=1/c^2+O(\log\log n/\log^{1/3}n)Ï(c)=1/c2+O(loglogn/log1/3n). For large enough nnn the value of Ï(c)\rho(c)Ï(c) tends to 1/c21/c^21/c2.

Nearest Neighbor Search

entry.title: æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ 12 Frequent Itemsets and Association Rules
entry.content:
Frequent itemsets and association rules.

This problem aims to find a set of items that are bought together. These itemsets can be efficiently mined by exploiting the apriori principle of the support measure.

Frequent Itemsets Mining

Frequent itemsets: collections of objects that appear a minimum number of times in the baskets of the customers.

Set of ddd items I\mathcal II, set of nnn transactions identifiers T\mathcal TT.

Dataset D\mathcal DD is a set of pairs (i,t)âˆˆIÃ—T(i,t)\in\mathcal I\times\mathcal T(i,t)âˆˆIÃ—T.

A basket is a transaction-set t(D)={i1,â‹¯â€‰,iâˆ£tâˆ£}t(\mathcal D)=\{i_1,\cdots,i_{|t|}\}t(D)={i1â€‹,â‹¯,iâˆ£tâˆ£â€‹}.

An itemset is a subset of IâŠ†2II\subseteq2^\mathcal IIâŠ†2I items, where 2I2^\mathcal I2I is the powerset of all subsets of I\mathcal II.

Definition of support: For an itemset III we define the support Ïƒ(I)\sigma(I)Ïƒ(I) as the number of transactions that contain itemset III, i.e., Ïƒ(I)=âˆ£{tâˆˆTâˆ£IâŠ†t(D)}âˆ£\sigma(I)=|\{t\in\mathcal T|I\subseteq t(\mathcal D)\}|Ïƒ(I)=âˆ£{tâˆˆTâˆ£IâŠ†t(D)}âˆ£.

Frequent itemset mining problem finds all the itemsets IâŠ†2II\subseteq 2^\mathcal IIâŠ†2I that have a support Ïƒ(I)â‰¥minsup\sigma(I)\ge minsupÏƒ(I)â‰¥minsup. The support can be expressed as a number or a percentage, similarly to frequent subgraph mining in last lecture. If we have ddd items, we have potentially 2d2^d2d itemsets. Itemsets are typically represented in a lattice structure, in which the root is empty, and each node is the union of itemsets in the parent nodes. The question is how do we find frequent itemsets efficiently.

A naive solution. To count each itemset individually. This requires to construct 2d2^d2d itemsets and compte the frequency for each of them, reaching O(2dnw)\mathcal O(2^dnw)O(2dnw) time and O(d)\mathcal O(d)O(d) space, where www is the size of the largest transaction. ğŸ‘IMPRACTICAL!

The Apriori Algorithm

If X,Yâˆˆ2IX,Y\in 2^\mathcal IX,Yâˆˆ2I are two itemsets s.t. XâŠ†YX\subseteq YXâŠ†Y, the support Ïƒ(X)â‰¥Ïƒ(Y)\sigma(X)\ge\sigma(Y)Ïƒ(X)â‰¥Ïƒ(Y). We say that the support is anti-monotone.

The algorithm exploits the Apriori property by means of an iterative process that alternates frequent itemset generation, and candidate generation. Let CkC_kCkâ€‹ be the candidate itemsets of size kkk, let LkL_kLkâ€‹ be the frequent itemsets of size kkk. The Apriori algorithm starts from the intuition that, instead of generating all the itemsets, the candidates of size kkk should only contain frequent itemsets of size kâˆ’1k-1kâˆ’1.

Pseudo-code

Input: Data D\mathcal DD, items I\mathcal II, minimum support minsupminsupminsup.

  1. kâ†1k\gets 1kâ†1

  2. C1â†IC_1\gets\mathcal IC1â€‹â†I

  3. while Ckâ‰ âˆ…C_k\neq\emptyCkâ€‹î€ =âˆ… do

    // frequent itemset generation

    • Scan DB to find which itemsets in CkC_kCkâ€‹ are frequent, put them into LkL_kLkâ€‹

    // candidate generation

    • Use LkL_kLkâ€‹ to generate a collection of candidate itemsets Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1â€‹ of size k+1k+1k+1.
    • kâ†k+1k\gets k+1kâ†k+1

Candidate generation. It constructs the candidate itemsets of size k+1k+1k+1 by combining frequent itemsets of size kkk. For simplicity, we assume that itemsets are ordered. Also we assume that itemsets in LkL_kLkâ€‹ are ordered. We can generate candidates of size k+1k+1k+1 by joining two itemsets of size kkk that share the first kâˆ’1k-1kâˆ’1 items. In a database terms, we are computing a self-join between the list of candidates of size kkk using the first kâˆ’1k-1kâˆ’1 columns as joining attributes.

Once a new candidate is generated, we can check whether all the ordered subsets are also frequent, i.e., they are in the set LkL_kLkâ€‹. This ensure the correct application of the Apriori principle. The generatiion of candidates Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1â€‹ proceeds as follows

  1. Self-join LkL_kLkâ€‹: create set Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1â€‹ by joining frequent kkk-itemsets that share the first kâˆ’1k-1kâˆ’1 items
  2. Pruning step: Remove a Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1â€‹ candidate if a kkk-subset is not frequent.

Frequent itemset generation. Important step: counting the support for each of the candidates CkC_kCkâ€‹. Speed up by using hash map. Better solution: hash-tree.

Itemsets of size k=2k=2k=2. For a typical shop-basket data, the number of k=2k=2k=2 items is by far the largest among other kkk values. Itâ€™s important to have efficient, in-memory optimizations. There are 2 approaches:

  1. counting all pairs using a triangular matrix

    requires 4 bytes per pair

  2. keeping a table for triples [i,j,c][i,j,c][i,j,c], where ccc is the count of the pair of items (ii,ij)(i_i,i_j)(iiâ€‹,ijâ€‹).

    require 12 bytes per pair but only for those pair with positive count.

Factors Affecting the Complexity

  • Minimum support threshold
  • Dimensionality of the dataset
  • Size of Database
  • Average transaction width. It may increase max length of frequent itemsets and traversals of has h tree.

Association Rule Mining

It is a refinement of frequent itemsets, in which an itemset is frequent conditionally to another itemset. E.g. {a,b}â‡’{c,d,e}\{a,b\}\Rarr\{c,d,e\}{a,b}â‡’{c,d,e} means when items a,ba,ba,b occurs, also c,d,ec,d,ec,d,e occur.

Definition of association rule. It is an implication of the form Xâ‡’YX\Rarr YXâ‡’Y as the number of items YYY appears in transactions that contain XXX, i.e., Î³(Xâ‡’Y)=Ïƒ(XâˆªY)Ïƒ(X)\gamma(X\Rarr Y)=\frac{\sigma(X\cup Y)}{\sigma(X)}Î³(Xâ‡’Y)=Ïƒ(X)Ïƒ(XâˆªY)â€‹.

The association rule mining task finds all rules at least with support minsupminsupminsup and confidence minconÂ fmin con\ fminconÂ f. The algorithm is apriori + additional step to generate the rules. The algorithm proceeds:

  1. Frequent itemset generation. Generate all itemsets whose support is greater than minsupminsupminsup
  2. Rule generation. Generate rules with confidence at least minconÂ fmincon\ fminconÂ f for each frequent itemset, where a rule is a partitioning of a frequent itemset into left-hand-side and right-hand-side.

So the pending issue for new algorithm is how do we generate such rules.

Rule Generation

The naive way: enumerate all the LHS and RHS. The process takes for each frequent itemset SSS all subsets LâŠ‚SL\subset SLâŠ‚S and generates rules of the form Sâˆ’Lâ‡’LS-L\Rarr LSâˆ’Lâ‡’L that satisfy minimum confidence.

Does confidence posses the desired apriori property? Not in the strict sense.

Luckily, the apriori property holds for rules generated from the same itemset.

If we move items from LHS to RHS as the support in the denominator of the confidence increases. As such, if a rule Xâ‡’YX\Rarr YXâ‡’Y from the same item has confidence â‰¤minconf\le minconfâ‰¤minconf all rules in which the RHS is a superset of YYY also have low confidence and can be pruned.

So we generate a candidate rule by merging 2 rules that share the same prefix on RHS. This process is essentially the apriori algorithm on RHS.

FP-Tree and FP-Growth

A smarter and more intricate algorithm, that exploits a tree structure called FP-tree.

FP-tree construction. An FP-tree is a prefix tree that contains a compressed representation of the transaction database. Each transaction in the FP-tree is a overlapping path in the tree.

The first step before constructing the tree is sorting the itemsets to ensure the uniqueness of the prefixes.

  1. The construction of the FP-tree starts from an empty node. Each node has a label corresponding to an item and a counter, corresponding to the number of transactions in the paths containing the item.
  2. For each transaction follow the prefix-path and increase the counters on the way.
  3. If at some point we reach a leaf node we expand the path adding nodes with counter 1.
  4. Add a pointer between nodes that refer to the same item.

We add a header table corresponding to the first (from the left of the tree) correspondence of the item.

The final size of the tree depends on the redundancy in the transactions. In the best case, all transaction are the same and the FP-tree is a path. In worst case, all the transactions are different and the size of the tree is bigger than that of the data.

FP-Growth is an algorithm that takes the FP-tree as input and performs a divide-and-conquer strategy to enumerate all the frequent itemsets.

Pseudo-code

Itemsets mining with FP-Tree

Input: All frequent itemsets and their support

Output: The FP-tree, minimum support minsupminsupminsup

  1. Proceed in divide-and-conquer manner
  2. for each Items iâˆˆIi\in\mathcal IiâˆˆI do
    • Consider candidate itemsets CCC ending with iii
    • Recursion on CCC

The meta-algorithm works bottom-up. This means that for each possible last item, consider itemsets with last items one of items preceding it in the ordering.

The items are lexicographically ordered and the header-table contains the first occurrence of an item.

FP-Growth

Input: All frequent itemsets and their support

Output: The FP-tree, minimum support minsupminsupminsup

  1. Proceed in divide-and-conquer manner
  2. for each suffix XXX do
    • Construct a prefix-tree for XXX, compute support using header table and pointers
    • If XXX is frequent then
      • Recompute support
      • Prune infrequent items
      • Prune leaves and recur

However, the items counter of the items need to be updated as the global FP-tree contains the counters for all transactions, including those not ending with the considered suffix. The counters propagates bottom-up from the leaves to the root.

Once the counters are updated, if any of the labels have support less than minsupminsupminsup the node is pruned and the subtree of the node is attacked to the nodeâ€™s father. After pruning, the suffix is removed from the tree and the computation proceeds recursively bottom-up.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Efficient
  • Allows to compute support along with the frequent items.

ğŸ‘

  • Efficiency depends on the compaction factor
  • If the tree is bushy, the number of sub-problems to solve is large

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 11 Randomized Rounding for MAX SAT
entry.content:
MAX SAT and MAX CUT

randomized Â½ approximation for each problem

MAX SAT

aka maximum satisfiability problem

  • Input consists of nnn Boolean variables x1,â‹¯â€‰,xnx_1,\cdots,x_nx1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹, mmm clauses C1,â‹¯â€‰,CmC_1,\cdots,C_mC1â€‹,â‹¯,Cmâ€‹.
    • Clauses CjC_jCjâ€‹ consist of some number of variables and \or and a non-negative weight wjw_jwjâ€‹.
  • The objective of the problem is to find an assignment of xix_ixiâ€‹ that maximizes the weight of the satisfied clauses.
  • A clause is said to be satisfied if one of the unnegated variables is set to true, or one of the negated variables is set to false.

Some terminology:

  • literal. A variable xix_ixiâ€‹ or a negated variable xË‰i\bar x_ixË‰iâ€‹ is a literal, so that each clause consists of some number of literals.
    • xix_ixiâ€‹ is called positive literal
    • xË‰i\bar x_ixË‰iâ€‹ is called negative literal
  • length. The number of literals in a clause. Length of CiC_iCiâ€‹ is lil_iliâ€‹.
  • Clause of length 1 is unit clause.

WLOG, assume that no literal is repeated in a clause, at most one of xix_ixiâ€‹ and xË‰i\bar x_ixË‰iâ€‹ appears in a clause.

Assume the clauses are distinct.

A very straightforward use of randomization: set each xix_ixiâ€‹ to true independently with probability 1/21/21/2.

ğŸ¤”Theorem 1. Setting each xix_ixiâ€‹ to true with probability 1/21/21/2 independently gives a randomized 1/21/21/2-approximation algorithm for the MAX SAT problem.

Define indicator variable YjY_jYjâ€‹: 111 if clause jjj is satisfied and 000 otherwise.

Let WWW be a random variable that is equal to the total weight of the satisfied clauses, so that W=âˆ‘jwjYjW=\sum_jw_jY_jW=âˆ‘jâ€‹wjâ€‹Yjâ€‹.

Let OPTOPTOPT denote the optimum value of the MAX SAT instance. Then, by linearity of expectation, and the definition of the expectation of 0-1 random variable, we know

E[W]=âˆ‘j=1mwjE[Yj]=âˆ‘j=1mwjPrâ¡[CjÂ isÂ satisfied].\mathbb E[W]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\mathbb E[Y_j]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ is satisfied}].E[W]=j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹E[Yjâ€‹]=j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹Pr[Cjâ€‹Â isÂ satisfied].

For each CjC_jCjâ€‹, the probability that it is not satisfied is the probability that each positive literal in CjC_jCjâ€‹ is set to false and each negative literal is set to true, each of which happens with probability 1/21/21/2. Hence,

Prâ¡[CjÂ isÂ satisfied]=(1âˆ’(12)lj)â‰¥12,\Pr[C_j\text{ is satisfied}]=\left(1-(\frac{1}{2})^{l_j}\right)\ge\frac{1}{2},Pr[Cjâ€‹Â isÂ satisfied]=(1âˆ’(21â€‹)ljâ€‹)â‰¥21â€‹,

where the last inequality is a consequence of the fact that ljâ‰¥1l_j\ge1ljâ€‹â‰¥1. Hence,

E[W]â‰¥12âˆ‘j=1mwjâ‰¥12OPT,\mathbb E[W]\ge\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\ge\frac{1}{2}OPT,E[W]â‰¥21â€‹j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹â‰¥21â€‹OPT,

where the last inequality follows from the fact that the total weight is an easy upper bound on the optimal value, since each weight is assumed to be non-negative.

If ljâ‰¥kl_j\ge kljâ€‹â‰¥k for each clause jjj, the algorithm is a (1âˆ’(12)k)\left(1-(\frac{1}{2})^k\right)(1âˆ’(21â€‹)k)-approximation algorithm for such instances. Thus the longer the clauses, the better the approximation.

Consider lj=3l_j=3ljâ€‹=3 for all clauses, the problem turns into MAX E3SAT. By analysis above, this randomized algorithm gives guarantee of 7/87/87/8 approximation. Nothing better is possible for these instances unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

ğŸ¤”Theorem 2. If there is an (78+Ïµ)(\frac{7}{8}+\epsilon)(87â€‹+Ïµ)-approximation algorithm for MAX E3SAT for any constant Ïµ>0\epsilon\gt 0Ïµ>0, then P=NPP=NPP=NP.

MAX CUT

aka maximum cut problem

In this problem. the input is an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), along with a non-negative weight wijâ‰¥0w_{ij}\ge0wijâ€‹â‰¥0 for each edge (i,j)âˆˆE(i,j)\in E(i,j)âˆˆE. The goal is to partition the vertex set into two parts UUU and W=Vâˆ’UW=V-UW=Vâˆ’U, so as to maximize the weight of edges whose two endpoints are in different parts, one in UUU and another in WWW.

An edge with endpoints in both UUU and WWW is in the cut. In the case wij=1w_{ij}=1wijâ€‹=1 for each edge âˆˆE\in EâˆˆE, we have an unweighted MAX CUT problem.

We place each vertex vâˆˆVv\in VvâˆˆV into UUU independently with probability 1/21/21/2. As with the MAX SAT algorithm, this can be viewed as sampling a solution uniformly form the space of all possible solutions.

ğŸ¤”Theorem 3. If we place each vertex vâˆˆVv\in VvâˆˆV into UUU independently with probability 1/21/21/2, then we obtain a randomized 1/21/21/2-approximation algorithm for the maximum cut problem.

Consider a random variable XijX_{ij}Xijâ€‹ that is 111 if edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) is in the cut, and 000 otherwise.

Let ZZZ be the random variable equal to the total weight of edges in the cut, so that Z=âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆEwijXijZ=\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}X_{ij}Z=âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆEâ€‹wijâ€‹Xijâ€‹.

Let OPTOPTOPT denote the optimal value of the maximum cut instance. Then, as before, by linearity of expectation and the definition of expectation of a 0-1 random variable, we get that

E[Z]=âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆEwijE[Xij]=âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆEwijPrâ¡[(i,j)Â inÂ cut].\mathbb E[Z]=\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}\mathbb E[X_{ij}]=\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}\Pr[(i,j)\text{ in cut}].E[Z]=(i,j)âˆˆEâˆ‘â€‹wijâ€‹E[Xijâ€‹]=(i,j)âˆˆEâˆ‘â€‹wijâ€‹Pr[(i,j)Â inÂ cut].

The probability that a specific edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) is in the cut: since the 2 endpoints are placed in the sets independently, they are in different sets with probability equal to 1/21/21/2. Hence,

E[Z]=12âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆEwijâ‰¥12OPT,\mathbb E[Z]=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{(i,j)\in E}w_{ij}\ge\frac{1}{2}OPT,E[Z]=21â€‹(i,j)âˆˆEâˆ‘â€‹wijâ€‹â‰¥21â€‹OPT,

where the inequality follows directly from the fact that the sum of the non-negative weights of all edges is obviously an upper bound on the weight of the edges in an optimal cut.

Derandomization

Randomized algorithm for MAX SAT can be derandomized by replacing the randomized decision of whether to set xix_ixiâ€‹ to true with a deterministic one that will preserve the expected value of the solution. The decisions will be made sequentially.

Assume that x1x_1x1â€‹ is fixed, and other variables will be set true with probability 1/21/21/2. Intuitively we should choose the value of x1x_1x1â€‹ which maximize the expected value of WWW. In this way, we should maintain the algorithm that the expected value is at least half the optimum, while having fewer random variables left.

If E[Wâˆ£x1â†true]â‰¥E[Wâˆ£x1â†false]\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets true]\ge\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets false]E[Wâˆ£x1â€‹â†true]â‰¥E[Wâˆ£x1â€‹â†false], then we set x1x_1x1â€‹ to true, otherwise false. Then

E[W]=E[Wâˆ£x1â†ture]Prâ¡[x1â†true]+E[Wâˆ£xâ†false]Prâ¡[x1â†flase]=12(E[Wâˆ£x1â†true]+E[Wâˆ£x1â†false])\mathbb E[W]=\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets ture]\Pr[x_1\gets true]+\mathbb E[W|x\gets false]\Pr[x_1\gets flase]\\=\frac{1}{2}(\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets true]+\mathbb E[W|x_1\gets false])E[W]=E[Wâˆ£x1â€‹â†ture]Pr[x1â€‹â†true]+E[Wâˆ£xâ†false]Pr[x1â€‹â†flase]=21â€‹(E[Wâˆ£x1â€‹â†true]+E[Wâˆ£x1â€‹â†false])

By induction, we can set the sequence of variables better than 1/21/21/2.

Flipping Biased Coins

Consider MAX SAT instance with no unit clauses xË‰i\bar x_ixË‰iâ€‹. (This condition can be moved)

Suppose we set each xix_ixiâ€‹ to be true independently with probability p>12p\gt\frac{1}{2}p>21â€‹, then the probability that any given clause is satisfied is at least minâ¡(p,1âˆ’p2)\min(p,1-p^2)min(p,1âˆ’p2) for MAX SAT instances with no negated unit clauses.

å‡è®¾è¿™äº›å¸ƒå°”è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸å«æœ‰å•ä¸ªéå˜é‡ã€‚

å¯¹äºåªå«ä¸€ä¸ªå˜é‡çš„å¸ƒå°”è¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼Œæ»¡è¶³çš„æ¦‚ç‡ä¸º ppp.

å¯¹äºå«æœ‰è‡³å°‘ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡çš„å¸ƒå°”è¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼Œå‡è®¾ xix_ixiâ€‹ æœ‰ aaa ä¸ªï¼ŒxË‰j\bar x_jxË‰jâ€‹ æœ‰ bbb ä¸ªï¼Œåˆ™è¯¥è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸æ»¡è¶³çš„æ¦‚ç‡ä¸ºï¼š

Prâ¡[CkÂ notÂ satisfied]=(1âˆ’p)apbâ‰¤pa+bâ‰¤p2âˆ´Prâ¡[CkÂ satisfied]â‰¥1âˆ’p2\Pr[C_k\text{ not satisfied}]=(1-p)^ap^b\le p^{a+b}\le p^2\\\therefore\Pr[C_k\text{ satisfied}]\ge 1-p^2Pr[Ckâ€‹Â notÂ satisfied]=(1âˆ’p)apbâ‰¤pa+bâ‰¤p2âˆ´Pr[Ckâ€‹Â satisfied]â‰¥1âˆ’p2

ç°åœ¨å°±éœ€è¦å°† minâ¡(p,1âˆ’p2)\min(p,1-p^2)min(p,1âˆ’p2) æœ€å¤§åŒ–ã€‚

Best performance is p=1âˆ’p2â‡’pâ‰ˆ0.618p=1-p^2\Rarr p\approx0.618p=1âˆ’p2â‡’pâ‰ˆ0.618.

ğŸ¤”Theorem 4. Setting each xix_ixiâ€‹ to true with probability ppp independently gives a randomized minâ¡(p,1âˆ’p2)\min(p,1-p^2)min(p,1âˆ’p2)-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT instances with no negated unit clauses.

Let viv_iviâ€‹ be the weight of the unit clause xË‰i\bar x_ixË‰iâ€‹ if it exists in the instance, and let viv_iviâ€‹ be zero otherwise.

OPTOPTOPT has a tighter bound: OPTâ‰¤âˆ‘j=1mwjâˆ’âˆ‘i=1nviOPT\le\sum_{j=1}^mw_j-\sum_{i=1}^nv_iOPTâ‰¤âˆ‘j=1mâ€‹wjâ€‹âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹viâ€‹.

Let UUU be the set of indices of clauses of the instance excluding unit clauses of the form xË‰i\bar x_ixË‰iâ€‹. WLOG the weight of each clause xË‰i\bar x_ixË‰iâ€‹ is no greater than the weight of clause xix_ixiâ€‹. Thus âˆ‘jâˆˆUwj=âˆ‘j=1mwjâˆ’âˆ‘i=1nvi\sum_{j\in U}w_j=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j-\sum_{i=1}^nv_iâˆ‘jâˆˆUâ€‹wjâ€‹=âˆ‘j=1mâ€‹wjâ€‹âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹viâ€‹. Each xix_ixiâ€‹ is set to true with probability 0.6180.6180.618. So the algorithm produces

E[W]=âˆ‘j=1mwjPrâ¡[CjÂ satisfied]â‰¥âˆ‘jâˆˆUmwjPrâ¡[CjÂ satisfied]â‰¥pâ‹…âˆ‘jâˆˆUwj=pâ‹…(âˆ‘j=1mwjâˆ’âˆ‘i=1nvi)â‰¥pâ‹…OPT.\mathbb E[W]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\\\ge\sum_{j\in U}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\\\ge p\cdot\sum_{j\in U}w_j\\=p\cdot(\sum_{j=1}^mw_j-\sum_{i=1}^nv_i)\ge p\cdot OPT.E[W]=j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹Pr[Cjâ€‹Â satisfied]â‰¥jâˆˆUâˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹Pr[Cjâ€‹Â satisfied]â‰¥pâ‹…jâˆˆUâˆ‘â€‹wjâ€‹=pâ‹…(j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹âˆ’i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹viâ€‹)â‰¥pâ‹…OPT.

This algorithm can be derandomized using the method of conditional expectations.

Randomized Rounding

Biasing probability with which we set xix_ixiâ€‹ true yields an improved approximation algorithm. However, we gave each variable the same bias. We can do better by giving each variable its own bias!

Idea of randomized rounding:

  • First set up an integer programming formulation of the problem at hand in which there are 0-1 integer variables. 0-1 variable yiy_iyiâ€‹ for each Boolean variable xix_ixiâ€‹ s.t. yi=1y_i=1yiâ€‹=1 corresponds to xix_ixiâ€‹ set true.
  • The integer program is relaxed to a linear program by replacing the constraints yiâˆˆ{0,1}y_i\in\{0,1\}yiâ€‹âˆˆ{0,1} with 0â‰¤yiâ‰¤10\le y_i\le 10â‰¤yiâ€‹â‰¤1.
  • The fractional value yiâˆ—y_i^*yiâˆ—â€‹ is interpreted as the probability that yiy_iyiâ€‹ should be set to 111. In this case we set each xix_ixiâ€‹ to true with probability yiâˆ—y_i^*yiâˆ—â€‹ independently.

For MAX SAT problem, in addition to the variables yiy_iyiâ€‹, we introduce a variable zjz_jzjâ€‹ for each CjC_jCjâ€‹ that will be 111 if the clause is satisfied and 000 otherwise. For each clause CjC_jCjâ€‹ let PjP_jPjâ€‹ be the indices of the variables xix_ixiâ€‹ that are positive, NjN_jNjâ€‹ be negated in the clause.

We denote the clause CjC_jCjâ€‹ by

\bigvee_{i\in P_j}x_i\or\bigvee_{i\in N_j}\bar x_i.

Then the inequality

âˆ‘iâˆˆPjyi+âˆ‘iâˆˆNj(1âˆ’yi)â‰¥zj\sum_{i\in P_j}y_i+\sum_{i\in N_j}(1-y_i)\ge z_jiâˆˆPjâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹yiâ€‹+iâˆˆNjâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹(1âˆ’yiâ€‹)â‰¥zjâ€‹

must hold for CjC_jCjâ€‹ since if each variable that occurs positively in the clause is set to false and each variable that occurs negatively is set to true, then the clause is not satisfied, and zjz_jzjâ€‹ must be 000.

This yields integer programming formulation of MAX SAT problem:

  • maximize âˆ‘j=1mwjzj\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_jâˆ‘j=1mâ€‹wjâ€‹zjâ€‹
  • subject to âˆ‘iâˆˆPjyi+âˆ‘iâˆˆNj(1âˆ’yi)â‰¥zj\sum_{i\in P_j}y_i+\sum_{i\in N_j}(1-y_i)\ge z_jâˆ‘iâˆˆPjâ€‹â€‹yiâ€‹+âˆ‘iâˆˆNjâ€‹â€‹(1âˆ’yiâ€‹)â‰¥zjâ€‹, \forall C_j=\bigvee_{i\in P_j}x_i\or\bigvee_{i\in N_j}\bar x_i,
  • yiâˆˆ{0,1},i=1,â‹¯â€‰,ny_i\in\{0,1\},i=1,\cdots,nyiâ€‹âˆˆ{0,1},i=1,â‹¯,n
  • 0â‰¤zjâ‰¤1,j=1,â‹¯â€‰,m0\le z_j\le 1,j=1,\cdots,m0â‰¤zjâ€‹â‰¤1,j=1,â‹¯,m

ZLPâˆ—Z^*_{LP}ZLPâˆ—â€‹ is the optimum value of this linear program LPLPLP, then clearly the optimum value of integer program (IP) ZIPâˆ—=OPTZ^*_{IP}=OPTZIPâˆ—â€‹=OPT.

Let (yâˆ—,zâˆ—)(y^*,z^*)(yâˆ—,zâˆ—) be the optimum value of solution to the linear programming, relaxation. Consider the result of using randomized rounding, and setting xix_ixiâ€‹ to true with probability yiâˆ—y_i^*yiâˆ—â€‹ independently. Before we can begin the analysis, we will need 2 facts. The first is commonly called the arithmetic-geometric mean inequality, because it compares the arithmetic and geometric means of a set of numbers.

âˆi=1kaikâ‰¤1kâˆ‘i=1kai\sqrt[k]{\prod_{i=1}^ka_i}\le\frac{1}{k}\sum_{i=1}^ka_iki=1âˆkâ€‹aiâ€‹â€‹â‰¤k1â€‹i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹aiâ€‹

If fâ€²â€²(x)â‰¤0âˆ€xâˆˆ[0,1],f(0)=a,f(1)=b+af''(x)\le0\forall x\in[0,1],f(0)=a,f(1)=b+afâ€²â€²(x)â‰¤0âˆ€xâˆˆ[0,1],f(0)=a,f(1)=b+a, then f(x)â‰¥bx+aâˆ€xâˆˆ[0,1]f(x)\ge bx+a\forall x\in[0,1]f(x)â‰¥bx+aâˆ€xâˆˆ[0,1].

ğŸ¤”Theorem 5. Randomized rounding gives a randomized (1âˆ’1e)(1-\frac{1}{e})(1âˆ’e1â€‹)-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT.

Applying arithmetic-geometric mean inequality:

Prâ¡[CjÂ notÂ satisfied]=âˆiâˆˆPj(1âˆ’yiâˆ—)âˆiâˆˆNjyiâˆ—â‰¤[1lj(âˆ‘iâˆˆPj(1âˆ’yiâˆ—)+âˆ‘iâˆˆNjyiâˆ—)]lj\Pr[C_j\text{ not satisfied}]=\prod_{i\in P_j}(1-y_i^*)\prod_{i\in N_j}y_i^*\\\le\left[\frac{1}{l_j}(\sum_{i\in P_j}(1-y_i^*)+\sum_{i\in N_j}y_i^*)\right]^{l_j}Pr[Cjâ€‹Â notÂ satisfied]=iâˆˆPjâ€‹âˆâ€‹(1âˆ’yiâˆ—â€‹)iâˆˆNjâ€‹âˆâ€‹yiâˆ—â€‹â‰¤â£â¢â¡â€‹ljâ€‹1â€‹(iâˆˆPjâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹(1âˆ’yiâˆ—â€‹)+iâˆˆNjâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹yiâˆ—â€‹)â¦â¥â¤â€‹ljâ€‹

By rearranging terms,

[1lj(âˆ‘iâˆˆPj(1âˆ’yiâˆ—)+âˆ‘iâˆˆNjyiâˆ—)]lj=[1âˆ’1lj(âˆ‘iâˆˆNj(1âˆ’yiâˆ—)+âˆ‘iâˆˆPjyiâˆ—)]lj\left[\frac{1}{l_j}(\sum_{i\in P_j}(1-y_i^*)+\sum_{i\in N_j}y_i^*)\right]^{l_j}=\left[1-\frac{1}{l_j}(\sum_{i\in N_j}(1-y_i^*)+\sum_{i\in P_j}y_i^*)\right]^{l_j}â£â¢â¡â€‹ljâ€‹1â€‹(iâˆˆPjâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹(1âˆ’yiâˆ—â€‹)+iâˆˆNjâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹yiâˆ—â€‹)â¦â¥â¤â€‹ljâ€‹=â£â¢â¡â€‹1âˆ’ljâ€‹1â€‹(iâˆˆNjâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹(1âˆ’yiâˆ—â€‹)+iâˆˆPjâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹yiâˆ—â€‹)â¦â¥â¤â€‹ljâ€‹

By the inequality Optimum of LP â‰¥\geâ‰¥ Optimum of IP, we see

Prâ¡[CjÂ notÂ satisfied]â‰¤(1âˆ’zjâˆ—lj)lj.\Pr[C_j\text{ not satisfied}]\le\left(1-\frac{z_j^*}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}.Pr[Cjâ€‹Â notÂ satisfied]â‰¤(1âˆ’ljâ€‹zjâˆ—â€‹â€‹)ljâ€‹.

Function f(zjâˆ—)=1âˆ’(1âˆ’zjâˆ—lj)ljf(z_j^*)=1-\left(1-\frac{z_j^*}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}f(zjâˆ—â€‹)=1âˆ’(1âˆ’ljâ€‹zjâˆ—â€‹â€‹)ljâ€‹ is concave for ljâ‰¥1l_j\ge1ljâ€‹â‰¥1, then

Prâ¡[CjÂ satisfied]â‰¥1âˆ’(1âˆ’zjâˆ—lj)ljâ‰¥[(1âˆ’1lj)lj]zjâˆ—.\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\ge1-\left(1-\frac{z_j^*}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\\\ge\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]z_j^*.Pr[Cjâ€‹Â satisfied]â‰¥1âˆ’(1âˆ’ljâ€‹zjâˆ—â€‹â€‹)ljâ€‹â‰¥[(1âˆ’ljâ€‹1â€‹)ljâ€‹]zjâˆ—â€‹.

Therefore the expected value of the randomized rounding algorithm is

E[W]=âˆ‘j=1mwjPrâ¡[CjÂ satisfied]â‰¥âˆ‘j=1mwjzjâˆ—[(1âˆ’1lj)lj]â‰¥minâ¡kâ‰¥1[(1âˆ’1k)k]âˆ‘j=1mwjzjâˆ—.\mathbb E[W]=\sum_{j=1}^mw_j\Pr[C_j\text{ satisfied}]\\\ge\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]\\\ge\min_{k\ge1}\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{k}\right)^{k}\right]\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*.E[W]=j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹Pr[Cjâ€‹Â satisfied]â‰¥j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹zjâˆ—â€‹[(1âˆ’ljâ€‹1â€‹)ljâ€‹]â‰¥kâ‰¥1minâ€‹[(1âˆ’k1â€‹)k]j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹zjâˆ—â€‹.

[(1âˆ’1k)k]\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{k}\right)^{k}\right][(1âˆ’k1â€‹)k] is non-increasing. It approaches 1âˆ’1e1-\frac{1}{e}1âˆ’e1â€‹ from above as kkk tends to infinity. Thus we have

E[W]â‰¥minâ¡kâ‰¥1[(1âˆ’1k)k]âˆ‘j=1mwjzjâˆ—â‰¥(1âˆ’1e)OPT.\mathbb E[W]\ge\min_{k\ge1}\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{k}\right)^{k}\right]\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\ge(1-\frac{1}{e})OPT.E[W]â‰¥kâ‰¥1minâ€‹[(1âˆ’k1â€‹)k]j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹zjâˆ—â€‹â‰¥(1âˆ’e1â€‹)OPT.

This randomized rounding algorithm can be derandomized in the standard way using the method of conditional expectations.

è¿™ä¸ªè¯æ˜ä¸å¤ªä¼˜é›…ï¼Œå…¶å®å¯ä»¥ç”¨ exâ‰¥x+1e^x\ge x+1exâ‰¥x+1 è¿›è¡Œæ”¾ç¼©ï¼Œå°†ä¹˜ç§¯åŒ–ä¸º eee çš„æŒ‡æ•°å’Œçš„å½¢å¼ã€‚

ç„¶åå†ç”¨çº¿æ€§è§„åˆ’çš„ç»“æœè‡³å°‘ä¼˜äºæ•´æ•°çº¿æ€§è§„åˆ’çš„ç»“æœï¼Œå¾—åˆ° Prâ¡[Ci(x)=1]â‰¥1âˆ’expâ¡(âˆ’zjâˆ—)\Pr[C_i(x)=1]\ge1-\exp(-z_j^*)Pr[Ciâ€‹(x)=1]â‰¥1âˆ’exp(âˆ’zjâˆ—â€‹)ã€‚

Choosing the Better of 2 Solutions

Consider a given clause CjC_jCjâ€‹ of length ljl_jljâ€‹. The randomized rounding algorithm satisfies the clause with probability at least [(1âˆ’1lj)lj]zjâˆ—\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]z_j^*[(1âˆ’ljâ€‹1â€‹)ljâ€‹]zjâˆ—â€‹, while the unbiased randomized algorithm satisfies the clause with probability 1âˆ’2âˆ’ljâ‰¥(1âˆ’2âˆ’lj)zjâˆ—1-2^{-l_j}\ge(1-2^{-l_j})z_j^*1âˆ’2âˆ’ljâ€‹â‰¥(1âˆ’2âˆ’ljâ€‹)zjâˆ—â€‹.

When the clause is short, it is very likely to be satisfied by the randomized rounding algorithm, tough not by the unbiased randomized algorithm. When the clause is long, the opposite is true.

ğŸ¤”Theorem 6. Choosing the better of the two solutions given by the randomized rounding algorithm and the unbiased randomized algorithm yields a randomized 3/43/43/4-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT.

Let W1W_1W1â€‹ be a random variable denoting the value of the solution by randomized rounding algorithm.

Let W2W_2W2â€‹ be the results of unbiased randomized algorithm. To show:

E[maxâ¡(W1,W2)]â‰¥34OPT\mathbb E[\max(W_1,W_2)]\ge\frac{3}{4}OPT\\E[max(W1â€‹,W2â€‹)]â‰¥43â€‹OPT

Observe that

E[maxâ¡(W1,W2)]â‰¥E[12(W1+W2)]=12E[W1]+12E[W2]â‰¥12âˆ‘j=1mwjzjâˆ—[(1âˆ’1lj)lj]+12âˆ‘j=1mwj(1âˆ’2âˆ’lj)â‰¥âˆ‘j=1mwjzjâˆ—[12(1âˆ’(1âˆ’1lj)lj)+12(1âˆ’2âˆ’lj)].\mathbb E[\max(W_1,W_2)]\ge\mathbb E[\frac{1}{2}(W_1+W_2)]\\=\frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[W_1]+\frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[W_2]\\\ge\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{l_j}\right)^{l_j}\right]+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^mw_j(1-2^{-l_j})\\\ge\sum_{j=1}^mw_jz_j^*\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(1-(1-\frac{1}{l_j})^{l_j}\right)+\frac{1}{2}(1-2^{-l_j})\right].E[max(W1â€‹,W2â€‹)]â‰¥E[21â€‹(W1â€‹+W2â€‹)]=21â€‹E[W1â€‹]+21â€‹E[W2â€‹]â‰¥21â€‹j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹zjâˆ—â€‹[(1âˆ’ljâ€‹1â€‹)ljâ€‹]+21â€‹j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹(1âˆ’2âˆ’ljâ€‹)â‰¥j=1âˆ‘mâ€‹wjâ€‹zjâˆ—â€‹[21â€‹(1âˆ’(1âˆ’ljâ€‹1â€‹)ljâ€‹)+21â€‹(1âˆ’2âˆ’ljâ€‹)].

Claim that

[12(1âˆ’(1âˆ’1lj)lj)+12(1âˆ’2âˆ’lj)]â‰¥34\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(1-(1-\frac{1}{l_j})^{l_j}\right)+\frac{1}{2}(1-2^{-l_j})\right]\ge\frac{3}{4}[21â€‹(1âˆ’(1âˆ’ljâ€‹1â€‹)ljâ€‹)+21â€‹(1âˆ’2âˆ’ljâ€‹)]â‰¥43â€‹

for all positive integers ljl_jljâ€‹.

é€šè¿‡æ±‚å¯¼ç­‰æ–¹æ³•å¯ä»¥æ±‚å‡ºè¿™ä¸ªå¼å­çš„æœ€å°å€¼ï¼Œä¸å¤ªä¼˜é›…å•Šâ€¦â€¦

Notice that taking the best solution of the two derandomized algorithms gives at least half of sum of two results.

Thus taking the best solution of the two derandomized algorithms is a deterministic 3/43/43/4-approximation algorithm.

Non-linear Randomized Rounding

3/43/43/4-approximation algorithm for MAX SAT can be obtained by using randomized rounding with a non-linear function fff.

fff is a function from [0,1][0,1][0,1] to [1,0][1,0][1,0]

Select fff s.t. 1âˆ’4âˆ’yâ‰¤f(y)â‰¤4yâˆ’11-4^{-y}\le f(y)\le 4^{y-1}1âˆ’4âˆ’yâ‰¤f(y)â‰¤4yâˆ’1 for every yâˆˆ[0,1]y\in[0,1]yâˆˆ[0,1]. Such an fff does exist.

Use the similar analysis of linear randomized rounding.

entry.summary: LeÃ§on 13 Un aller simple

entry.title: Fair Division 7 Ex-ante and Ex-post Fairness
entry.content:
Objective: Explore randomized indivisible allocations (equivalent to fractional allocation) and their implications on fairness: the compatibility of Ex-ante and Ex-post fairness.

Activities: Study the paper Best of Both Worlds: Ex-Ante and Ex-Post Fairness in Resource Allocation.

What does Both worlds here means?

The indivisible allocation is randomized.

  • Before the allocation, each agent has a expected valuation for the bundle. Ex-ante WORLD I

  • After the allocation, each agent has its actual valuation for the bundle. Ex-post WORLD II

Iannis told me to ignore anything related to GROUP FAIRNESS.

Indivisible goods, additive valuations.

When RANDOMIZATION is allowed, it is possible to achieve envy-freeness.

When allocation is deterministic, achieving exact fairness is impossible but approximate notions such as EF1 can be guaranteed.

Goal: Achieve both simultaneously by randomized allocation that is fair ex-ante and approximately fair ex-post.

Algorithm that achieves ex-ante EF with ex-post EF1.

ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 + economic efficiency? impossible. âŒ

ex-ante EF + relaxed ex-post fairness + economic efficiency? feasible. âœ”ï¸

Introduction

If we allowed to randomize, then we can choose an agent uniformly at random and allocate the entire set of goods. This is trivially ex-ante envy-free since all agents receive the same distribution.

ex-ante å¯ä»¥ç†è§£ä¸ºé¢„æœŸçš„ï¼Œå…ˆéªŒçš„

ex-post å¯ä»¥ç†è§£ä¸ºå®æ–½ç¡®å®šåˆ†é…åçš„ï¼ŒåéªŒçš„

However, this allocation induces a large amount of envy ex-post because there are times when one agent receives everything while others receive nothing.

Some ex-post envy is unavoidable: 2 agents, 1 item.

EF1 always exists, which limits the ex-post envy, but still be unfair if some agents are systematically favored over others.

Question: Can we randomize over EF1 allocations s.t. the resulting randomized allocation is EF? aka ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

æœ¬è®ºæ–‡æå‡ºçš„æœŸæœ›æ— å«‰å¦’å’ŒåéªŒå«‰å¦’ç‰¹ä¸€ç‰©åˆ†é…ï¼Œå³

  • åˆ†é…å‰ï¼šæ‰€æœ‰æ™ºèƒ½ä½“è·å¾—çš„ä»·å€¼çš„æœŸæœ›æ˜¯ EF çš„

  • åˆ†é…åï¼šæ‰€æœ‰æ™ºèƒ½ä½“çœŸå®è·å¾—ä»·å€¼æ˜¯ EF1 çš„

This paper: Yes.

Basic Results

en-ante\ex-postProp1+EF11EF1EF1+POEF1+fPO

Possibility: Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1

Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1 can be achieved simultaneously.

Based on round-robin, with manipulation of agent order. Uniformly randomizing the agent ordering also achieves ex-ante proportionality.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 2. With additive valuations, randomized round-robin is ex-ante PROP and ex-post EF1.

Obviously, randomized round-robin is ex-post EF1. For ex-ante PROP, fix an agent iii, and suppose, without loss of generality, that vi,1â‰¥vi,2â‰¥â‹¯â‰¥vi,mv_{i,1}\ge v_{i,2}\ge\cdots\ge v_{i,m}vi,1â€‹â‰¥vi,2â€‹â‰¥â‹¯â‰¥vi,mâ€‹. Suppose m=cnm=cnm=cn for some positive integer ccc.

Since she appears in every position in the ordering with probability 1/n1/n1/n, her expected value is at least 1nâˆ‘k=1mâˆ‘câ€²=1cvi,(câ€²âˆ’1)n+k=1nâˆ‘j=1mgi,j\frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=1}^m\sum_{c'=1}^cv_{i,(c'-1)n+k}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{j=1}^mg_{i,j}n1â€‹âˆ‘k=1mâ€‹âˆ‘câ€²=1câ€‹vi,(câ€²âˆ’1)n+kâ€‹=n1â€‹âˆ‘j=1mâ€‹gi,jâ€‹, which matches her proportionality guarantee.

However, just by randomizing agent order, sometimes we fail to achieve ex-ante EF. Example omitted.

Noted that there are n!n!n! possible agent orders. For iii, some orders may better than the others.

Instead of starting from a method that guarantees ex-post EF1 and using it to achieve ex-ante EF, we do the opposite: Start from a fractional EF allocation and implement it using integral EF1 allocations.

Probabilistic serial is an algorithm that produces a fractional EF allocations.

  • serial eating protocol wherein all agents simultaneously start eating their respective favorite goods at the same constant speed.
  • Once a good is completely consumed by a subset of agents, each of those agents proceeds to eating her favorite available good at the same speed.
  • The algorithm terminates when all goods have been eaten, and fraction of each good consumed by an agent is allocated to her.

A very vivid algorithm

A useful property of this algorithm: it only uses the ordinal preferences of agents over goods, and computes an allocation that is ex-ante envy-free for any additive utilities consistent with the ordinal preferences. Thus, itâ€™s SD-EF.

Use a variant of probabilistic serial, recursive probabilistic serial, which provides the desired fairness guarantees, i.e., ex-ante EF and ex-post EF1.

Recursive Probabilistic Serial

Given as input a subset of goods Mâ€²âŠ†MM'\subseteq MMâ€²âŠ†M, the algorithm allows each agent to consume its favorite available good in Mâ€²M'Mâ€² out of those that have not yet been fully consumed at a rate of one good per unit time.

Let Xt=eating(Mâ€²,t)X^t=eating(M',t)Xt=eating(Mâ€²,t) denote the partial allocation obtained when the algorithm is run for ttt unit of time. Note that eating(M,âŒˆmnâŒ‰)eating(M,\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil)eating(M,âŒˆnmâ€‹âŒ‰) is equivalent to the outcome of the probabilistic serial algorithm.

    • âŒŠâˆ‘j=1mXijâŒ‹â‰¤âˆ‘j=1mAijkâ‰¤âŒˆâˆ‘j=1mXijâŒ‰\lfloor\sum_{j=1}^mX_{ij}\rfloor\le\sum_{j=1}^mA^k_{ij}\le\lceil\sum_{j=1}^mX_{ij}\rceilâŒŠâˆ‘j=1mâ€‹Xijâ€‹âŒ‹â‰¤âˆ‘j=1mâ€‹Aijkâ€‹â‰¤âŒˆâˆ‘j=1mâ€‹Xijâ€‹âŒ‰

The algorithm proceeds in stages. In each stages, the EATING procedure is run for one unit of time, after which every agent has consumed a total mass of one item.

Then, by theorem 1, this fractional partial allocation can be decomposed into integral allocations. By 3. of theorem 1, each agent receives exactly one item in each integral allocation in the support.

We interpret the weights w1,â‹¯â€‰,wqw^1,\cdots,w^qw1,â‹¯,wq as probabilities, and sample an integral allocation from this distribution before proceeding to the next stage.

The algorithm then fixes the assignments of the goods to the agents in accordance with the aforementioned integral partial allocation, and repeats the eating procedure with the reduced set of goods.

In the final stage of the algorithm, fewer than nnn goods might remain, in which case some agents do not receive any good under the integral allocation. The full procedure is describe in pseudo code.

Ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1

  3. for t=1t=1t=1 to âŒˆmnâŒ‰\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceilâŒˆnmâ€‹âŒ‰ do
    • Xtâ†X^t\getsXtâ† eating(Mt,1)(M^t,1)(Mt,1) // eating protocol for one unit of time
    • BvN: Xt=âˆ‘k=1â„“wt,kAt,kX^t=\sum_{k=1}^\ell w^{t,k}A^{t,k}Xt=âˆ‘k=1â„“â€‹wt,kAt,k // decomposition from theorem 1
    • Btâ†At,kB^t\gets A^{t,k}Btâ†At,k with probability wt,kw^{t,k}wt,k // sampling step
    • Mt+1â†Mtâ•²â‹ƒiâˆˆNBitM^{t+1}\gets M^t\diagdown\bigcup_{i\in N}B_i^tMt+1â†Mtâ•²â‹ƒiâˆˆNâ€‹Bitâ€‹ // fix the assignments according to the sampled allocation
    • Biâ†Biâ‹ƒt=1âŒˆmnâŒ‰BitB_i\gets B_i\bigcup_{t=1}^{\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil}B_i^tBiâ€‹â†Biâ€‹â‹ƒt=1âŒˆnmâ€‹âŒ‰â€‹Bitâ€‹ for all iâˆˆNi\in NiâˆˆN // update integral allocation
  4. return BBB

Every integral allocation returned by Algorithm 1 satisfies EF1.
