By lemma 1, for every t<âŒˆmnâŒ‰t\lt\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceilt<âŒˆnmâ€‹âŒ‰, we have vi(gi,t)â‰¥vi(gk,t+1)v_i(g_{i,t})\ge v_i(g_{k,t+1})viâ€‹(gi,tâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(gk,t+1â€‹) because gk,t+1âˆˆMt+1g_{k,t+1}\in M^{t+1}gk,t+1â€‹âˆˆMt+1. Hence,

vi(Ai)â‰¥âˆ‘i=1âŒˆmnâŒ‰âˆ’1vi(gi,t)â‰¥âˆ‘i=2âŒˆmnâŒ‰vi(gi,t)=vi(Akâ•²{gk,1})v_i(A_i)\ge\sum_{i=1}^{\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil-1}v_i(g_{i,t})\ge\sum_{i=2}^{\lceil\frac{m}{n}\rceil}v_i(g_{i,t})=v_i(A_k\diagdown\{g_{k,1}\})viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥i=1âˆ‘âŒˆnmâ€‹âŒ‰âˆ’1â€‹viâ€‹(gi,tâ€‹)â‰¥i=2âˆ‘âŒˆnmâ€‹âŒ‰â€‹viâ€‹(gi,tâ€‹)=viâ€‹(Akâ€‹â•²{gk,1â€‹})

which establishes EF1.

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 2. The randomized allocation implemented by algorithm 1 is ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

By lemma, it is indeed ex-post EF1.

Notice that each agent eats her preferred available good at each point in time during the eating algorithm. Therefore, for any iteration ttt, the partial fractional allocation XtX^tXt computed by the eating procedure in iteration ttt is EF.

The rest is induction.

Since Recursive Probabilistic Serial takes only the ordinal references of agents over goods as input, thus it is in fact ex-ante SD-EF + ex-post SD-EF1.

A Polynomial-Time Algorithm for Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1

Full randomized allocation constructed by Algorithm 1 require exponential time.

Approach to reducing the support size is to use the CarathÃ©odoryâ€™s theorem from convex analysis: If a point xâˆˆRdx\in\mathbb R^dxâˆˆRd lies in the convex hull of a set PPP, then xxx can be expressed as a convex combination of at most d+1d+1d+1 vertices of PPP.

Any fractional allocation XXX is a point in an nÃ—mn\times mnÃ—m-dimensional space. By CarathÃ©odoryâ€™s theorem, if it is a convex combination of integral allocations in the support {A1,â‹¯â€‰,Aâ„“}\{A^1,\cdots,A^\ell\}{A1,â‹¯,Aâ„“}, then it can also be written as a convex combination of at most nm+1nm+1nm+1 allocations from this set.

This establishes the existence of a convex combination with small support, it does not automatically provide an efficient algorithm for converting a convex combination with large support to one with small support.

In the modification of recursive probabilistic serial, we ensure that the support size remains mn+1mn+1mn+1 after every step of â€œbranching outâ€.

Every step of branching out can increase the support size of mn+1mn+1mn+1 to (nm+1)â‹…p(m,n)(nm+1)\cdot p(m,n)(nm+1)â‹…p(m,n). Thus we need a way to reduce the support size from at most (mn+1)â‹…p(m,n)(mn+1)\cdot p(m,n)(mn+1)â‹…p(m,n) to at most nm+1nm+1nm+1.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 3. There is a polynomial-time algorithm, that given a polytope P\mathcal PP with a strong separation oracle and a point yâˆˆPy\in\mathcal PyâˆˆP, returns a representation of yyy as a convex combination of dimâ¡(P)+1\dim(\mathcal P)+1dim(P)+1 vertices of P\mathcal PP.

Notice that at the end of the first iteration t=1t=1t=1, the fractional partial allocation X1X^1X1 consists of a polynomial number of integral allocations in its support, i.e., X1=âˆ‘k=1â„“w1,kA1,kX^1=\sum_{k=1}^\ell w^{1,k}A^{1,k}X1=âˆ‘k=1â„“â€‹w1,kA1,k, where â„“=p(m,n)\ell=p(m,n)â„“=p(m,n) for some polynomial ppp. Consider the polytope P1\mathcal P^1P1 formed by the convex hull of the integral allocations A1,1,â‹¯â€‰,A1,â„“A^{1,1},\cdots,A^{1,\ell}A1,1,â‹¯,A1,â„“ as follows

\mathcal P^1=\{z:z=\sum_k\alpha_kA^{1,k}\text{ where }(\alpha_k\ge0\forall k\in[\ell])\and(\sum_k\alpha_k=1)\}

polytope å¤šèƒä½“

  1. Convexity: A polytope is a convex set, meaning that for any two points inside the polytope, the line segment connecting them lies entirely within the polytope.
  2. Finite Set of Vertices: A polytope is defined by a finite set of vertices (or corners) in Euclidean space. These vertices are the extreme points of the polytope and determine its shape.
  3. Higher-Dimensional Analogues: Just as a polygon is a two-dimensional polytope and a polyhedron is a three-dimensional polytope, polytopes can exist in any finite number of dimensions. For example, a four-dimensional polytope is called a polytope, and a five-dimensional polytope is called a polychoron.
  4. Faces: The faces of a polytope are the lower-dimensional subsets of the polytope that are themselves polytopes. For example, in a three-dimensional polyhedron, the faces are the polygons that form its surface.
  5. Simplexes and Polygons: Simplexes are special types of polytopes that are defined as the convex hull of a set of affinely independent points. A simplex in two dimensions is a triangle, and in three dimensions, it is a tetrahedron. Polygons are also considered special cases of polytopes.

Observe that P1\mathcal P^1P1 admits a polynomial-time strong separation oracle. One can decide in polynomial time whether a given point yâˆˆRnÃ—my\in\mathbb R^{n\times m}yâˆˆRnÃ—m belongs to P1\mathcal P^1P1, or return a separating hyper-plane if it doesnâ€™t. This implies that an (nm+1)(nm+1)(nm+1)-sized decomposition of X1X^1X1, as guaranteed by CarathÃ©odoryâ€™s theorem can be computed in polynomial time.

Having computed an (nm+1)(nm+1)(nm+1)-sized decomposition of X1X^1X1, we obtain at most nm+1nm+1nm+1 sub-instances in each of which we re-run algorithm. Notice that this result in a probability distribution over (nm+1)â‹…p(n,m)(nm+1)\cdot p(n,m)(nm+1)â‹…p(n,m) deterministic allocations at the end of the second iteration. Re-invoke algorithmic version of CarathÃ©odoryâ€™s theorem to obtain a decomposition over at most mn+1mn+1mn+1 of these integral allocations in polynomial time.

Produced randomized allocation has support that is a subset of the support of the randomized allocation produced by recursive probabilistic serial. Hence, ex-post EF1 of this modified procedure follows immediately from lemma 1.

Like algorithm 1, this algorithm produces the same ex-ante SD-EF + ex-post SD-EF1.

Impossibility: ex-ante PROP + ex-post EF1 + ex-post fPO

The previous lacks efficiency.

ex-ante PO â‡’\Rarrâ‡’ ex-post fPO â‡’\Rarrâ‡’ ex-post PO

ex-ante EF + ex-post PO + ex-post EF1? Not solveâ€¦

How about stronger one, ex-post fPO? The answer is negative for ex-ante PROP + ex-post EF1 + ex-post fPO.

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 3. There exists an instance with additive valuations in which no randomized allocation is simultaneously ex-ante PROP + ex-post EF1 + ex-post fPO.

It suffices to give an instance with unique EF1 + fPO allocation which violates PROP.

2 goods g1,g2g_1,g_2g1â€‹,g2â€‹, 2 agent a1,a2a_1,a_2a1â€‹,a2â€‹ with valuations

g1g_1g1â€‹g2g_2g2â€‹
a1a_1a1â€‹12
a2a_2a2â€‹13

This instance has exactlly 2 integral EF1 allocations: A=({g1},{g2})A=(\{g_1\},\{g_2\})A=({g1â€‹},{g2â€‹}) and B=({g2},{g1})B=(\{g_2\},\{g_1\})B=({g2â€‹},{g1â€‹}). Itâ€™s easy to check that BBB is not fPO, since it is Pareto dominated by a fractional allocation XXX that assign g1g_1g1â€‹ to a1a_1a1â€‹ and splits g2g_2g2â€‹ equally between 2 agents.

AAA is fPO, maximizing the utilitarian social welfare.

Observe that AAA violates PROP since v1(A1)=v1(g1)<12v1(g1âˆªg2)v_1(A_1)=v_1(g_1)\lt\frac{1}{2}v_1(g_1\cup g_2)v1â€‹(A1â€‹)=v1â€‹(g1â€‹)<21â€‹v1â€‹(g1â€‹âˆªg2â€‹).

Additionally, ex-ante EF and ex-ante GF imply ex-ante PROP, thus these are also incompatible with ex-post EF1 + PO.

Since ex-ante PO implies ex-post fPO, thus ex-ante (PROP + PO) and ex-ante (EF + PO) are incompatible with ex-post EF1.

Possibility: ex-ante GF + ex-post PROP1 + ex-post EF11

Omitted

Characterizing MNW

Seems related to GF, can be omitted.

The Case of Bads

â€œBadsâ€ here means chores. aka all items are negative valued.

Let MMM be set of mmm bads. Fractional, integral and randomized allocations are defined analogously as in the case of goods.

However the agents have non-positive valuation functions. There are differences when defining fairness notions.

PROP1, aka proportionality up to one bad. An integral allocation AAA is PROP1 if for every agent iii, either vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(M)/nv_i(A_i)\ge v_i(M)/nviâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(M)/n or there exists a bad jâˆˆAij\in A_ijâˆˆAiâ€‹ s.t. vi(Aiâ•²{j})â‰¥vi(M)/nv_i(A_i\diagdown\{j\})\ge v_i(M)/nviâ€‹(Aiâ€‹â•²{j})â‰¥viâ€‹(M)/n, where vi(M)v_i(M)viâ€‹(M) is iiiâ€™s valuation for all bads.

EFk, aka envy-freeness up to kkk bads. An integral allocation AAA is EFk if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h, there âˆƒSiâŠ†Ai\exist S_i\subseteq A_iâˆƒSiâ€‹âŠ†Aiâ€‹ with âˆ£Siâˆ£â‰¤k|S_i|\le kâˆ£Siâ€‹âˆ£â‰¤k s.t. vi(Aiâ•²Si)â‰¥vi(Ah)v_i(A_i\diagdown S_i)\ge v_i(A_h)viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹â•²Siâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Ahâ€‹).

EF11, aka envy-freeness up to one bad more-and-less. An integral allocation AAA is EF11 if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h s.t. Aiâ‰ âˆ…A_i\neq\emptyAiâ€‹î€ =âˆ…, we have vi(Aiâ•²{ji})â‰¥vi(Ahâˆª{jh})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{j_i\})\ge v_i(A_h\cup\{j_h\})viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹â•²{jiâ€‹})â‰¥viâ€‹(Ahâ€‹âˆª{jhâ€‹}) for some bads jiâˆˆAij_i\in A_ijiâ€‹âˆˆAiâ€‹ and jhâˆˆÌ¸Ahj_h\not\in A_hjhâ€‹î€ âˆˆAhâ€‹.

Ex-ante EF + Ex-post EF1 for Bads

Recursive Probabilistic Serial and its polynomial-time variant only use ordinal preferences of agents over goods.

Problem here: Can we construct an ordinal preference over bads in which the bads are sorted in a non-increasing order of the agentâ€™s valuation for them.

Both RPS and its polynomial-time variant are always ex-post EF2 for bads.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 6. For additive valuation functions over bads, recursive probabilistic serial and its polynomial variant produce randomized allocation that are ex-ante EF and ex-post EF2.

eating procedure is EF because agents are forced to eat bads at the same rate and an agent is always eating a bad that she prefers the most among all bads not fully consumed.

Since each XtX^tXt is EF, a probability distribution over XtX^tXt in different branches is also envy-free. Hence, the expected fractional allocation induced in step ttt is EF for each ttt. Hence, ex-ante EF.

For ex-post EF2, let AAA be an integral allocation produced by RPS. By lemma 1 still holds for bads.

For t<âŒˆm/nâŒ‰t\lt\lceil m/n\rceilt<âŒˆm/nâŒ‰, if bi,tb_{i,t}bi,tâ€‹ denotes the bad allocated to agent iii in iteration ttt, then agent iii prefers bi,tb_{i,t}bi,tâ€‹ to all bads in Mt+1M^{t+1}Mt+1.

When t<âŒŠm/nâŒ‹t\lt\lfloor m/n \rfloort<âŒŠm/nâŒ‹, we know that another agent hhh must receive a bad in round t+1â‰¤âŒŠm/nâŒ‹t+1\le\lfloor m/n \rfloort+1â‰¤âŒŠm/nâŒ‹. Hence, for all agents i,hâˆˆNi,h\in Ni,hâˆˆN and all t<âŒŠm/nâŒ‹t\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloort<âŒŠm/nâŒ‹, we have vi(bi,t)â‰¥vi(bh,t+1)v_i(b_{i,t})\ge v_i(b_{h,t+1})viâ€‹(bi,tâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(bh,t+1â€‹).

Summing over t<âŒŠm/nâŒ‹t\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloort<âŒŠm/nâŒ‹, we get

vi({bi,t:1â‰¤t<âŒŠm/nâŒ‹})â‰¥vi({bh,t:2â‰¤tâ‰¤âŒŠm/nâŒ‹})â‰¥vi(Ah)v_i(\lbrace b_{i,t}:1\le t\lt\lfloor m/n\rfloor\rbrace)\ge v_i(\lbrace b_{h,t}:2\le t\le\lfloor m/n\rfloor\rbrace)\ge v_i(A_h)viâ€‹({bi,tâ€‹:1â‰¤t<âŒŠm/nâŒ‹})â‰¥viâ€‹({bh,tâ€‹:2â‰¤tâ‰¤âŒŠm/nâŒ‹})â‰¥viâ€‹(Ahâ€‹)

In the LHS, there are at most 2 bads missing from AiA_iAiâ€‹:

  • The bad allocated to agent iii in round âŒŠm/nâŒ‹\lfloor m/n\rfloorâŒŠm/nâŒ‹
  • Tge bad which may be allocated tot agent iii in the final round âŒˆm/nâŒ‰\lceil m/n\rceilâŒˆm/nâŒ‰

Q.E.D.

Naturally, the algorithm also produces ex-ante SD-EF + ex-post SD-EF2.

When mmm is a multiple of nnn, it turns out that the allocation is in fact ex-post EF1.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 5. For additive valuation functions over bads, recursive probabilistic serial and its polynomial-time variant from Section 3.2 produce randomized allocations that are ex-ante envy-free (EF) and ex-post envy-free up to one bad (EF1) whenever the number of bads is divisible by the number of agents.

Proof by proposition 6.

If nnn divides mmm, we guarantee that there is only one bad missing from the LHS, which is that allocated to agent iii in round m/nm/nm/n.

Simple modification of RPS, simply add a number of â€œdummy badsâ€ which all agent value at 000 s.t. the total number of bads becomes divisible by the number of nnn, then run RPS to compute ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1.

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 6. For additive valuation over bads, there always exists a randomized allocation that is ex-ante EF + ex-post EF1 which can be computed in polynomial time.

What about fair division of mixed manna?

Each item can be either a good or a bad for each agent.

EF1 can be generalized to the mixed manna setting. It requires that if iii envies hhh, then the envy can be eliminated by either removing one item from agent hhhâ€™s bundle (which must be a good for iii), or one item from agent iiiâ€™s bundle (which must be a bad for iii).

EF1 aka envy-freeness up to one item. An integral allocation AAA is EF1 if for every pair of agent i,hi,hi,h, either iii does not envy hhh, or there exists an item oâˆˆAiâˆªAho\in A_i\cup A_hoâˆˆAiâ€‹âˆªAhâ€‹ s.t. vi(Aiâ•²{o})â‰¥vi(Ahâ•²{o})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{o\})\ge v_i(A_h\diagdown\{o\})viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹â•²{o})â‰¥viâ€‹(Ahâ€‹â•²{o}).

The algorithm of this paper achieve the relaxation of EF1 in mixed manna setting, w-EF1.

w-EF1 aka weak envy-freeness up to one item. An integral allocation AAA is w-EF1 if for every pair i,hi,hi,h, either iii does not envy hhh, or there exists a good ohâˆˆAho_h\in A_hohâ€‹âˆˆAhâ€‹ and/or a bad oiâˆˆAio_i\in A_ioiâ€‹âˆˆAiâ€‹ s.t. vi(Aiâ•²{oi})â‰¥vi(Ahâ•²{oh})v_i(A_i\diagdown\{o_i\})\ge v_i(A_h\diagdown\{o_h\})viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹â•²{oiâ€‹})â‰¥viâ€‹(Ahâ€‹â•²{ohâ€‹}).

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 7. For additive valuation in the mixed manna setting, there always exists a randomized algorithm producing ex-ante EF + ex-post w-EF1, which can be computed in polynomial time.

Add dummy items to guarantee that mmm is a integer multiple of nnn, and remove them at the end.

When we run RPS on such instance, we can again apply the same argument as in the proof in proposition 6. That is equivalent to ex-post w-EF1 guarantee.

Of course, this results is also ex-ante SD-EF and ex-post SD-w-EF1 for mixed manna.

Ex-ante GF + Ex-post PROP1 + Ex-post EF11 for Bads

Omitted

Discussion

â“Open question:

  • ex-ante PROP + ex-post (EF1 + PO)
  • ex-ante EF + ex-post (EF1 + PO)

Difficulty: hard to analyze the methods of finding EF1 + PO allocations.

â“Open question:

  • Does there always exist an integral EF1 + PO allocation in which agent iii doesnâ€™t envy agent jjj?
  • What about an integral EF1 + PO allocation in which agent iii does not envy any other agent?
  • Given a priority ordering over the agents, does there always exist an EF1 + PO allocation in which no agent envies an agent with lower priority?

Other possible work direction: EFX/MMS for ex-post fairness?

How about ex-ante and ex-post fairness guarantees in voting, matching and public decision-making?

entry.title: æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ 11 Frequent Subgraph Mining
entry.content:
A labeled graph is a triple G=(V,E,â„“)G=(V,E,\ell)G=(V,E,â„“) where â„“:VâˆªEâ†’L\ell:V\cup E\rarr Lâ„“:VâˆªEâ†’L is a labeling function assigning a label from a set of labels LLL to each node and each edge.

Definition of frequency: it is encoded into a support measure that return the number of occurrences of the subgraph in the graph.

FSM in Graph Collections

A graph collection aka a graph database is a set D={G1,G2,â‹¯â€‰,Gn}\mathcal D=\{G_1,G_2,\cdots,G_n\}D={G1â€‹,G2â€‹,â‹¯,Gnâ€‹} of labeled graphs Gi=(Vi,Vi,â„“i),iâˆˆ[1,n]G_i=(V_i,V_i,\ell_i),i\in[1,n]Giâ€‹=(Viâ€‹,Viâ€‹,â„“iâ€‹),iâˆˆ[1,n].

Since a subgraph is uniquely identified by the nodes and edges of a certain graph, we need to relax the definition, so that it counts the occurrences of that subgraph in different graphs.

A graph G1(V1,E1,â„“1)G_1(V_1,E_1,\ell_1)G1â€‹(V1â€‹,E1â€‹,â„“1â€‹) is isomorphic åŒæ„ to a graph G2=(V2,E2,â„“2)G_2=(V_2,E_2,\ell_2)G2â€‹=(V2â€‹,E2â€‹,â„“2â€‹) if there exists a bijective function f:V1â†’V2f:V_1\rarr V_2f:V1â€‹â†’V2â€‹ such that if uâˆˆV1u\in V_1uâˆˆV1â€‹ then f(u)âˆˆV2f(u)\in V_2f(u)âˆˆV2â€‹ and â„“1(u)=â„“2(f(u))\ell_1(u)=\ell_2(f(u))â„“1â€‹(u)=â„“2â€‹(f(u)) and if (u,v)âˆˆE1(u,v)\in E_1(u,v)âˆˆE1â€‹ then (f(u),f(v))âˆˆE2(f(u),f(v))\in E_2(f(u),f(v))âˆˆE2â€‹ and â„“1((u,v))=â„“2((f(u),f(v)))\ell_1((u,v))=\ell_2((f(u),f(v)))â„“1â€‹((u,v))=â„“2â€‹((f(u),f(v))).

If a graph G1G_1G1â€‹ is isomorphic to a subgraph of another graph GGG, we say G1G_1G1â€‹ is subgraph isomorphic to GGG. Subgraph isomorphism is NP-complete, which graph isomorphism is NP.

Denote: GâŠ‘G1G\sqsubseteq G_1GâŠ‘G1â€‹ a subgraph isomorphism from GGG to G1G_1G1â€‹.

Given a collection of graphs D={G1,G2,â‹¯â€‰,Gn}\mathcal D=\{G_1,G_2,\cdots,G_n\}D={G1â€‹,G2â€‹,â‹¯,Gnâ€‹} and a graph GGG, the support set DG\mathcal D_GDGâ€‹ is the subset of D\mathcal DD, s.t. GGG is subgraph isomorphic to every graph in Gâ€²âˆˆDGG'\in\mathcal D_GGâ€²âˆˆDGâ€‹, i.e., DG={Gâ€²âˆˆDâˆ£GâŠ‘Gâ€²}\mathcal D_G=\{G'\in\mathcal D|G\sqsubseteq G'\}DGâ€‹={Gâ€²âˆˆDâˆ£GâŠ‘Gâ€²}. The support supâ¡(G)\sup(G)sup(G) of GGG is the proportion Ïƒ(G)=âˆ£DGâˆ£âˆ£Dâˆ£\sigma(G)=\frac{|\mathcal D_G|}{|\mathcal D|}Ïƒ(G)=âˆ£Dâˆ£âˆ£DGâ€‹âˆ£â€‹.

The Frequent Subgraph Mining FSM problem in collection of graphs D={G1,G2,â‹¯â€‰,Gn}\mathcal D=\{G_1,G_2,\cdots,G_n\}D={G1â€‹,G2â€‹,â‹¯,Gnâ€‹} finds all the subgraphs GGG having at least support minâ¡supâ¡\min\supminsup, i.e., Ïƒ(G)â‰¥minâ¡supâ¡\sigma(G)\ge\min\supÏƒ(G)â‰¥minsup.

Downward Closure Property

  • Downward closure is the property under which a support measure decreases by expanding a pattern. In particular in our case supâ¡(G)â‰¤supâ¡(Gâ€²)\sup(G)\le\sup(G')sup(G)â‰¤sup(Gâ€²) if Gâ€²âŠ‘GG'\sqsubseteq GGâ€²âŠ‘G.

The downward closure property leads to 2 different family of approaches: apriori-based approaches and pattern-growth approaches.

Apriori-based Approaches

This approaches stem from the observation that any subgraph of a frequent subgraph must be frequent as well.

FSG is one of the first methods that utilizes the apriori principle. The algorithm builds on the idea that a frequent kkk-subgraph is built on top of frequent (kâˆ’1)(k-1)(kâˆ’1)-subgraphs, where kkk indicates the number of edges.

The algorithm simply starts enumerating frequent 111-subgraphs and 222-subgraphs and store them into the set F1,F2F_1,F_2F1â€‹,F2â€‹ respectively.

Similarly, FkF_kFkâ€‹ is the set of frequent kkk-subgraphs. FSG then builds larger kkk-subgraphs by merging the subgraphs obtained in the previous iteration.

Pseudo code

  1. F1â†F_1\getsF1â€‹â† frequent 111-subgraphs with counts
  2. F2â†F_2\getsF2â€‹â† frequent 222-subgraphs with counts
  3. kâ†3k\gets3kâ†3
  4. while Fkâˆ’1â‰ âˆ…F_{k-1}\neq\emptyFkâˆ’1â€‹î€ =âˆ… do
    • candidate_generation: get CkC_kCkâ€‹, the set of candidate kkk-subgraphs from Fkâˆ’1F_{k-1}Fkâˆ’1â€‹
    • candidate_pruning: for a candidate to be frequent, each (kâˆ’1)(k-1)(kâˆ’1)-subgraph should be frequent
    • frequency_pruning: scan D\mathcal DD, count occurrences of subgraphs in CkC_kCkâ€‹
    • Fkâ†{câˆˆCkâˆ£Ïƒ(c)â‰¥minâ¡supâ¡}F_k\gets\{c\in C_k|\sigma(c)\ge\min\sup\}Fkâ€‹â†{câˆˆCkâ€‹âˆ£Ïƒ(c)â‰¥minsup}
    • kâ†k+1k\gets k+1kâ†k+1
  5. return âˆªi=1kFi\cup_{i=1}^kF_iâˆªi=1kâ€‹Fiâ€‹

each of 3 steps run isomorphism checks to understand whether some candidate is isomorphic to any of the other candidates. Moreover, in order to compute the support of a subgraph the algorithm runs subgraph isomorphism on all the candidate graphs in CkC_kCkâ€‹. FSG employs heuristics to reduce the number of isomorphism tests at each iteration.

Candidate Generation

Generate candidates by merging the frequent (kâˆ’1)(k-1)(kâˆ’1)-subgraphs. The main idea is to first detect cores to generate the candidates easily. A core is the maximum common subgraph among two subgraphs. Although generating the core requires to run subgraph isomorphism, in practice

  1. one core is common to many subgraphs.
  2. the subgraphs are typically small.

Candidate pruning

In order to prune the candidates we can check if every subgraph of a candidate is also frequent. In theory, this requires to perform isomorphism tests for each of the candidateâ€™s subgraph.

In order to hash a graph, we require a signature, i.e., a numeric representation, that is unique for each graph. This is possible through canonical labeling. Canonical labeling, finds a unique representation of a graph in a smart manner. In particular, FSG empolys a canonical scheme that reorders the column and the rows of the adjacency matrix. The string obtained by reading the sequence of node and edge labels in the column of the matrix that is smallest lexicographic string among all of those obtained by reordering is the canonical code and is unique, i.e., code(G)=minâ¡code(M)âˆ£Mcode(G)=\min code(M)|Mcode(G)=mincode(M)âˆ£M is adjacency matrix.

It seems that this method effectively solves graph isomorphism in O(1)\mathcal O(1)O(1). However, this is not the case as the canonical labeling is obtained by a, potentially exponential, number of reordering of the adjacency matrix. By reordering, we are computing automorphisms over the graph. In practice, not all the permutations lead to a valid matrix and can be pruned by simple heuristics.

Frequency Counting

Frequency counting requires to scan the data to find which graphs contain a subgraph. In frequency counting, most of the subgraph isomorphism tests can be avoided with a simple shortcut.

Let TID(Gâ€²),TID(Gâ€²â€²)TID(G'),TID(G'')TID(Gâ€²),TID(Gâ€²â€²) be the set of graphs in the collection D\mathcal DD that contain the subgraph Gâ€²G'Gâ€² and Gâ€²â€²G''Gâ€²â€², respectively. If we merge the two patterns, it follows immediately that TID(merge(Gâ€²,Gâ€²â€²))âŠ†TID(Gâ€²)âˆ©TID(Gâ€²â€²)TID(merge(G',G''))\subseteq TID(G')\cap TID(G'')TID(merge(Gâ€²,Gâ€²â€²))âŠ†TID(Gâ€²)âˆ©TID(Gâ€²â€²). As such all the graphs in (TID(Gâ€²)âˆªTID(Gâ€²â€²))â•²(TID(Gâ€²)âˆ©TID(Gâ€²â€²))(TID(G')\cup TID(G''))\diagdown(TID(G')\cap TID(G''))(TID(Gâ€²)âˆªTID(Gâ€²â€²))â•²(TID(Gâ€²)âˆ©TID(Gâ€²â€²)) can be ignored as they will not contribute to the support.

ğŸ‘

  • Finds all frequent subgraphs.
  • Easy to include heuristics to reduce the computation time.

ğŸ‘

  • FSG generates the same subgraph a large number of times.
  • The canonical labeling scheme is quadratic in the size of the subgraph.
  • FSG requires several isomorphism and subgraph isomorphism tests.

Pattern-growth Approaches

It follows a different philosophy.

Start first with empty subgraphs and progressively expand these subgraphs by adding one edge at the time. The pattern expands always in a certain order to redundancy as much as possible.

gSpan is the most famous algorithm in the pattern-growth family.

gSpan organizes the patterns in a prefix-tree, a data structure for alphabetically ordered string that store string prefixes as nodes of a tree. However, graphs do not have a predefined order of traversal, or a unique way of enumerating the nodes.

To create a prefix-tree of non-repeating patterns gSpan:

  1. Defines a traversal over the nodes in the graphs
  2. Identifies in advance which nodes of a subgraph to expand
  3. Defines a total ordering over the subgraphs, so as to detect duplicate patterns.

Node Traversal

gSpan traverses the subgraphs in a DFS manner, that means that the next node vjv_jvjâ€‹ to visit after viv_iviâ€‹ is the first in the list of neighbors N(i)N(i)N(i). A DFS vist defines a spanning-tree over the nodes in the subgraph. The edges in the spanning tree are called forward edges; the remaining edges are called backward edges.

In the beginning of the DFS a counter assigns a unique identifier to each node. The counter represents the discovery time of the node.

Rightmost Expansion

Since a DFS defines a specific traversal and the order of the visit is market by a counter, there is only one way to add an edge to the subgraph, namely expanding from the rightmost path. The rightmost path is the path from the root of the spanning tree to the leaf with the highest identifier.

Total Ordering

The main innovation of gSpan is to treat canonical labeling as a DFS-visit and thus ensure a reduced number of operations and redundant subgraphs.

DFS Codes

Representation of a graph that is comparable among other DFS codes. Such a comparison as a total ordering for which a minimum exists. The minimum DFS-code is a canonical labeling of a graph.

Definition of DFS-edge. Itâ€™s a tuple (i,j,â„“(i),â„“((i,j)),â„“(j))(i,j,\ell(i),\ell((i,j)),\ell(j))(i,j,â„“(i),â„“((i,j)),â„“(j)) where i,ji,ji,j are identifiers given by the DFS traversal order, â„“(i),â„“((i,j)),â„“(j)\ell(i),\ell((i,j)),\ell(j)â„“(i),â„“((i,j)),â„“(j) are the labels of node iii, edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) and node jjj.

DFS-code for a graph G=(V,E,â„“)G=(V,E,\ell)G=(V,E,â„“) is a sequence âŸ¨e1,â‹¯â€‰,etâŸ©\langle e_1,\cdots,e_t\rangleâŸ¨e1â€‹,â‹¯,etâ€‹âŸ© where each eie_ieiâ€‹ is a DFS-edge and t=âˆ£Eâˆ£t=|E|t=âˆ£Eâˆ£.

Valid DFS-codes. Precedence order â‰º\precâ‰º on DFS-edges corresponding to the DFS traversal. Given 2 DFS-edges e1e_1e1â€‹ connecting nodes with discovery time (i1,j1)(i_1,j_1)(i1â€‹,j1â€‹) and e2e_2e2â€‹ connecting nodes with discovery time (i2,j2)(i_2,j_2)(i2â€‹,j2â€‹). A DFS-code is valid if it complies to:

  1. i1=i2i_1=i_2i1â€‹=i2â€‹ and j1<j2â‡’e1â‰ºe2j_1\lt j_2\Rarr e_1\prec e_2j1â€‹<j2â€‹â‡’e1â€‹â‰ºe2â€‹ backward edges ordering
  2. i1<j1i_1\lt j_1i1â€‹<j1â€‹ and j1=i2â‡’e1â‰ºe2j_1=i_2\Rarr e_1\prec e_2j1â€‹=i2â€‹â‡’e1â€‹â‰ºe2â€‹ forward edges ordering
  3. e1â‰ºe2e_1\prec e_2e1â€‹â‰ºe2â€‹ and e2â‰ºe3â‡’e1â‰ºe3e_2\prec e_3\Rarr e_1\prec e_3e2â€‹â‰ºe3â€‹â‡’e1â€‹â‰ºe3â€‹ transitive property

Total ordering and minimum codes. A graph can have multiple valid DFS-codes depending on the DFS traversal order. gSpan further defines a total ordering over the DFS-codes so to define a minimum DFS-code for a graph.

The minimum DFS-code is unique and a canonical labeling of the graph. This implies that 2 graphs are isomorphic iff they have the same DFS-code.

Let Î±,Î²\alpha,\betaÎ±,Î² two DFS-codes. We say Î±â‰ºÎ²\alpha\prec\betaÎ±â‰ºÎ² iff either of the following conditions are true:

  • âˆƒt,0â‰¤tâ‰¤minâ¡(n,m)\exist t,0\le t\le\min(n,m)âˆƒt,0â‰¤tâ‰¤min(n,m) s.t. ak=bka_k=b_kakâ€‹=bkâ€‹ for k<tk\lt tk<t and atâ‰ºebta_t\prec_e b_tatâ€‹â‰ºeâ€‹btâ€‹
  • ak=bka_k=b_kakâ€‹=bkâ€‹ for 0â‰¤kâ‰¤m0\le k\le m0â‰¤kâ‰¤m and nâ‰¥mn\ge mnâ‰¥m

Simply speaking, Î±â‰ºÎ²\alpha\prec\betaÎ±â‰ºÎ² if either 1. Î±\alphaÎ± and Î²\betaÎ² are equal up to some point ttt and the next corresponding DFS-edges is s.t. atâ‰ºebta_t\prec_e b_tatâ€‹â‰ºeâ€‹btâ€‹, or 2. Î±\alphaÎ± and Î²\betaÎ² are the same in terms of DFS-edges but Î²\betaÎ² contains more edges.

We need to define â‰ºe\prec_eâ‰ºeâ€‹: Let at=(ia,ja,Lia,Lia,ja,Lja),bt=(ib,jb,Lib,Lib,jb,Ljb)a_t=(i_a,j_a,L_{i_a},L_{i_a,j_a},L_{j_a}),b_t=(i_b,j_b,L_{i_b},L_{i_b,j_b},L_{j_b})atâ€‹=(iaâ€‹,jaâ€‹,Liaâ€‹â€‹,Liaâ€‹,jaâ€‹â€‹,Ljaâ€‹â€‹),btâ€‹=(ibâ€‹,jbâ€‹,Libâ€‹â€‹,Libâ€‹,jbâ€‹â€‹,Ljbâ€‹â€‹) be two DFS-edges. We say atâ‰ºebta_t\prec_e b_tatâ€‹â‰ºeâ€‹btâ€‹ if

  1. Both are forward edges
    • ib<iai_b\lt i_aibâ€‹<iaâ€‹ OR
    • ib=iai_b=i_aibâ€‹=iaâ€‹ and the labels of aaa are lexicographical less than labels of bbb, in order of tuple.
  2. Both are backward edges
    • jaâ‰¤jbj_a\le j_bjaâ€‹â‰¤jbâ€‹ OR
    • ja=jbj_a=j_bjaâ€‹=jbâ€‹ and the edge label of aaa is lexicographical less than the one of bbb.
  3. ata_tatâ€‹ is backward and btb_tbtâ€‹ is forward.

The above enforce a total order on DFS-codes and, as such, the min-DFS(GGG) of a graph GGG is a canonical labeling of GGG.

DFS-code tree. It allows also to organize data into DFS-tree that is prefix tree. Because the codes have a precedence order. If min-DFS(G1G_1G1â€‹)={a0,a1,â‹¯â€‰,an}=\{a_0,a_1,\cdots,a_n\}={a0â€‹,a1â€‹,â‹¯,anâ€‹} and min-DFS(G2G_2G2â€‹)={a0,a1,â‹¯â€‰,an,b}=\{a_0,a_1,\cdots,a_n,b\}={a0â€‹,a1â€‹,â‹¯,anâ€‹,b}, then G1G_1G1â€‹ is parent of G2G_2G2â€‹, since min-DFS(G1G_1G1â€‹) is a prefix of min-DFS(G2G_2G2â€‹).

Given a parent-child relationship defined, we can construct a DFS Tree. An interesting property of the DFS-tree is that an in-order traveersal follows DFS lexicographic order.

gSpan algorithm

Input: Collection of graphs D\mathcal DD, minimum support minâ¡supâ¡\min\supminsup

Output: Frequent subgraph set SSS

  1. Let SSS be frequent one-edge subgraphs in D\mathcal DD using DFS code.
  2. Sort SSS in lexicographic order
  3. Nâ†SN\gets SNâ†S
  4. for each nâˆˆNn\in NnâˆˆN do
    • GSpanExtend(D,n,minâ¡supâ¡,S)(\mathcal D,n,\min\sup,S)(D,n,minsup,S)
  5. return SSS

GSpanExtend(D,n,minâ¡supâ¡,S)(\mathcal D,n,\min\sup,S)(D,n,minsup,S) // checking minimality of DFS-code is computationally expensive

  1. if nnn not minimal then return

  2. else

    • Sâ†SâˆªnS\gets S\cup nSâ†Sâˆªn

    • for each Rightmost expansion eee of nnn do

      • if Î´(e)â‰¥minâ¡supâ¡\delta(e)\ge\min\supÎ´(e)â‰¥minsup then

        GSpanExtend(D,n,minâ¡supâ¡,S)(\mathcal D,n,\min\sup,S)(D,n,minsup,S)

ğŸ‘

  • Finds all frequent subgraphs.
  • Generates less redundant subgraphs.

ğŸ‘

  • Works only in collections of graphs.
  • Generally slow for low minâ¡supâ¡\min\supminsup.

Frequent Subgraph Mining on a Single Graph

If the support is defined a the number of time a specific subgraph appears, the downward property does not hold anymore as bigger subgraphs can have a larger support.

We defined a support measure to be admissible if for any graph PPP and any subgraph QâŠ‘PQ\sqsubseteq PQâŠ‘P, the support of PPP is not larger than the support of QQQ. In the last few years, a number of admissible support measures have appeared. These include,

  • Maximum independent set support (MIS): Based on maximum number of non-overlapping matches
  • Harmful overlap support (HO): Based on number of patterns for which no multi-node subgraph is identical
  • Minimum image-based support (MNI): Based on the number of times a node in the pattern is mapped into a distinct node in the graph.

MIS Support

The maximum independent set support ÏƒMIS\sigma_{MIS}ÏƒMISâ€‹ counts how many times a pattern maps to a subgraph that does not overlap to any other subgraphs. The computation of MIS is as follows

  1. Construct an overlap graph GO=(VO,EO)G_O=(V_O,E_O)GOâ€‹=(VOâ€‹,EOâ€‹), in which the set of nodes VOV_OVOâ€‹ is the set of matches of a pattern PPP into a graph GGG and E_O=\{(f_1,f_2)|f_1,f_2\in V_O\or f_1\neq f_2\neq f_1\sqcap f_2\neq\empty\}, i.e., EOE_OEOâ€‹ has an edge among each pair of overlapping matches.
  2. Compute the ÏƒMIS\sigma_{MIS}ÏƒMISâ€‹ as the size of the maximum independent set of nodes in the overlap graph.

Recall that the maximum finding the maximum independent set of NP-hard.

Harmful Overlap Support

The HO support is less restrictive than MIS support as it considers overlap only those matchings of a pattern that share one are more edges. Two matching subgraph are connected through a node are not considered overlapping.

NMI Support

The minimum image-based support is even less restrictive as it considers the minimum number of times a node of the pattern matches a node in the graph.

Definition of MNI. Let f1,â‹¯â€‰,fmf_1,\cdots,f_mf1â€‹,â‹¯,fmâ€‹ be the set of isomorphism of a pattern P:âŸ¨VP,EP,â„“PâŸ©P:\langle V_P,E_P,\ell_P\rangleP:âŸ¨VPâ€‹,EPâ€‹,â„“Pâ€‹âŸ© in a graph GGG. Let F(v)=âˆ£{f1(v),â‹¯â€‰,fm(v)}âˆ£F(v)=|\{f_1(v),\cdots,f_m(v)\}|F(v)=âˆ£{f1â€‹(v),â‹¯,fmâ€‹(v)}âˆ£ be the number of distinct mappings of a node vâˆˆVPv\in V_PvâˆˆVPâ€‹ to a node in GGG by functions f1,â‹¯â€‰,fmf_1,\cdots,f_mf1â€‹,â‹¯,fmâ€‹. The MNI

ÏƒMNI(P)Â ofPÂ inÂ GÂ isÂ ÏƒMNI(P)=minâ¡{F(v),vâˆˆVP}\sigma_{MNI}(P)\ of P\ in\ G\ is\ \sigma_{MNI}(P)=\min\{F(v),v\in V_P\}ÏƒMNIâ€‹(P)Â ofPÂ inÂ GÂ isÂ ÏƒMNIâ€‹(P)=min{F(v),vâˆˆVPâ€‹}

Since MNI considers one node at the time, given the matching of pattern in the graph, NMI support can be computed in polynomial time.

Approaches for Large Graphs

With an anti-monotone support measure, we can apply any previous support measure such as gSPAN, just changing how the support is computed and leaving the rest unchanged. Such approaches are called grow-and-store

  • Add all frequent edges to the list of frequent subgraphs
  • Extend frequent subgraphs to larger candidates
  • Compute candidate frequency (find all occurrences)
  • Repeat step 2 until no more frequent subgraphs is found

One of the methods that exploits and optimizes gSpan is GraMi

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 10 Invertible Bloom Filters
entry.content:
Brief Introduction

Invertible Bloom Lookup Table (abbr. IBLT)

a fancy hash-table stores key-value pair (x,y)(x,y)(x,y)

space budget: ttt

Guarantee

It â€œworksâ€ when the number of key-value pairs, nnn, in table has nâ‰¤tn\le tnâ‰¤t.

â€œtemporarilyâ€ stops working if n>tn\gt tn>t.

starts working again if nnn drops below ttt.

Operations

(x,y) is key-value pair.

insert(x,y), delete(x,y), get(x), listentries.

Details

Start with table with kâ‰¥3k\ge3kâ‰¥3 rows, m=2Ã—tm=2\times tm=2Ã—t columns.

In each row, we have a hash function h1,â‹¯â€‰,hkh_1,\cdots,h_kh1â€‹,â‹¯,hkâ€‹.

hih_ihiâ€‹ is universal.

Each of the entry, called cell, stores values:

  • count
  • key_sum
  • value_sum

Insert Operation

  1. for i=1i=1i=1 to kkk
    • c=A[i][hi(x)]c=A[i][h_i(x)]c=A[i][hiâ€‹(x)]
    • c.count++c.count++c.count++
    • c.key_sum+=xc.key\_sum+= xc.key_sum+=x
    • c.value_sum+=yc.value\_sum+=yc.value_sum+=y

Delete Operation

â€œundoâ€ insert operation

We must know the pair is there before deletion.

  1. for i=1i=1i=1 to kkk
    • c=A[i][hi(x)]c=A[i][h_i(x)]c=A[i][hiâ€‹(x)]
    • c.countâˆ’âˆ’c.count--c.countâˆ’âˆ’
    • c.key_sumâˆ’=xc.key\_sum-= xc.key_sumâˆ’=x
    • c.value_sumâˆ’=yc.value\_sum-=yc.value_sumâˆ’=y

Get Operation

slightly different from min sketch count

  1. ret=âˆret=\inftyret=âˆ

  2. for i=1i=1i=1 to kkk

    • c=A[i][hi(x)]c=A[i][h_i(x)]c=A[i][hiâ€‹(x)]

    • if c.count==0c.count==0c.count==0 return â€œnot thereâ€

    • else if c.count==1c.count==1c.count==1 then

      • if c.key_sum==xc.key\_sum==xc.key_sum==x

        return c.value_sumc.value\_sumc.value_sum

      • else return â€œnot thereâ€

  3. return â€œdonâ€™t knowâ€

Probability of Success
